reviews.content: Wow! Wow! Wow!Blown away!I don't want to say much. I can't give anything away.This is a movie society needs. It makes you think.There is dual plot and it is lovely, concerning and entertaining.

Beautifully acted by the lovely main star and a number of the supporting cast. Great vocals. Excellent film. Would thoroughly recommend, especially if you like emotive movies with depth of feeling. Also strong themes of family, loyalty, coming of age, and some romance too. Super.

Took me a while before viewing this movie as the subject matter seemed a bit on the sombre side.How wrong I was!Superfilm: thoughtful, amusing with a brilliant script and direction.Plus great music which can be heard again on Spotify.Every single performer gave a 1st class credible performance.A young woman in a family of deaf people has to choose whether to stay with them or follow her musical dreams.One devasting moment near the end of the picture where people are at a concert listening to singers when the perspective changes to show how such a concert is heard by the deaf.Believe it ir not I thought the actor playing the music teacher stole the show!The movie well deserved the Oscar for best picture that it won:8/10.

Best Picture Oscar winners tend to be big screen epics or a movie that packs an emotional punch.CODA (Child of Deaf Adults) is another low/moderate budget independent film that has won the big prize at the Oscars in recent years.Set in the fishing town of Gloucester, Massachusetts. Ruby Rossi (Emilia Jones) is a high school student who has deaf parents and a deaf older brother.Before she starts school, she is out in a trawler with her father Frank (Troy Kostur) and brother Leo as the sole hearing person. The price they get for each catch gets lower and lower, while costs gets higher.At school Rose is shy. She stinks of fish, because of her parents deafness, she only learned how to talk properly when she started school.Rose shows talent as a singer. Her music teacher Mr Villalobos wants her to audition for a prestigious music school after she graduates.That puts Rose at odds with her parents who want her to stay with them, especially her mother Jackie (Marlee Matlin.) She also has to balance music lessons with the demands of her family's new fishing venture.There is no epic scope here even much of an emotional rollercoaster. It does avoid the schmaltz of the movie of the week approach.Where CODA soars is in the close knit family dynamics. The Rossi's are regarded as outsiders. No one else communicates with them much. Even regarded as freaks by others in the fishing community.The family appear to be unconventional but they feel real. Mum and dad have the hots for each other, they do not realise how much noise they make during lovemaking. Causing embarrassment for Rose.There are some nice touches. Jackie telling Rose that she was afraid if she could ever bond with a daughter who had full hearing. When the family go to the school music recital. They just hear silence and are too far away for the brother to lip read for them.It is a small scale feel good movie with many familiar ingredients in the screenplay. British actress Emilia Jones shows a lot of talent as Rose.It would not had been my pick for the Best Picture Oscar but it does have a lot of heart.

In my opinion...this movie have the capacity to win the best movie category..hope so .. seriously..all the characters fully justify their roles specially the acting of Troy and Emilia was amazing. Love all the songs as well. Truly worth of my time. Kudos.

I don't give ten stars out on a whim,but this film deserves it, is beautifully acted and scored.the film in a oasis of calm in world of turmoil.it deserved more than its limited release so it could hopefully put forward for the Oscar's.please see it.

reviews.review_title: I honestly cannot remember the last time I was so MOVED by a film
reviews.content: CODA restored my belief in taste.As a filmmaker for over 26 years, I am usually incredibly disappointed by most of the (contemporary) films I watch. Most of the time, I am left wondering "how did this get green lit?" But every so often, I am pleasantly surprised.CODA was a refreshing respite from super heroes and comic books.Everything about this film IMPRESSED me.Not since Children of A Lesser God, Mr. Holland's Opus or The Miracle Worker, have I been so deftly educated in the struggles, frustrations and victories of living with a lifelong challenge.CODA is a REAL story, no CGI, no super heroes, no over exaggerated anything. Just a pure insightfully told story, so beautiful in its delivery and interpretations.The acting is exceptional kudos to Emilia Jones as the hearing girl, with Marlee Matlin and Troy Kotsur as her Deaf parents and Daniel Durant as her Deaf brother. Eugenio Derbez is a sheer delight.Kostur is so skilled at conveying emotion with his incredibly expressive gestures. And funny. To me, he is a very strong contender for the Oscar. It would be a travesty if he did not win. Marlee Matlin was breathtakingly brilliant, as always.And Jones' voice is so pure. And free of all the Christina Aguilera runs and forced vocal gymnastics, what a refreshing change.In the last 10 years, I can honestly say I have been rarely moved to tears in anything I watch. (I watch anywhere from 40-60 films per month.) This film picked its moments with such finesse and expertise, Sian Heder timed each moment like a finely skilled artist.This is one NOT to miss.

I have been looking forward to this movie...it didn't let me down but I just felt like it wasn't the gem I was hoping it to be.It was a very sweet story. It has heart. It is made with care and thoughtful at the forefront.I love films because they can give you a look into life's that you don't get to experience or see in your own life. I think this movie does that great. It is a snapshot of a deaf family with a CODA.This can make the movie a little bit slow at times because there isn't much moving the plot forward but it is just nice seeing the life that they live.Marlee Martlin had to fight production and threaten to drop out the film because they first refused to hire anymore deaf actors. That is absolutely gross. In the end she won and they hired all real life deaf actors to play all the deaf characters. I think things like this are important because it adds nuance to a subject matter like this. These actors know the characters lives on a personal leaves and it adds to the movie.It has so much heart but it's not done in a sickly sweet way. It feels earnest!

If you can get past the sappiness of the singing parts, the movie is quite enjoyable. The singing is an essential part of the movie, but I felt they did not need to focus on her doing full-length songs. The characters were very fun to watch.

reviews.review_title: Very Inspiring Film With A Moral Message And Comedy
reviews.content: CODA is a very inspiring film with an overall good script and moral message. I also love the comedy in this movie.CODA is about an 18-year-old named Ruby who is the only one in her family of four without a hearing impairment. Her father is a fisherman, and she needs to help her dad with fishing since he can't hear. For example, if he violates a fishing code, the Coast Guard calls him, but he cannot respond because he can't hear the call. That's when Ruby comes in handy. Ruby's passion is singing. Her dream is to go to the Berklee College of Music. She finds out about a chorus group and joins it, which leads to some conflicts-primarily that her family relies on her, but she also wants to live her life and go to college.CODA, which stands for "child of deaf adults", is an outstanding film (with many awards and nominations) that is a remake of the 2014 French film, La Famille Bélier. Sian Heder wrote and directed this beautiful adapted screenplay. Not only is this film heartwarming and comical at the same time, but it also lets the audience experience what it is to be deaf to the point of feeling vulnerable by not experiencing the joy of a live concert. My favorite part is when Ruby performs a song on stage with her family watching in the crowd. This is the most interesting and heartwarming scene because when they cut out the audio you get to see the dad's point of view. You really feel what he experiences as a deaf person.There are many morals to this film, but the main one is that no matter what you suffer from or who you are-or even how you look-we are all humans. We should all be treated equally, and we are each unique in our own way. CODA does have some sexual scenes and foul language.I give CODA 5 out of 5 stars and recommend it for ages 13 to 18, plus adults. CODA is available now on Apple TV. By Ethan P., KIDS FIRST!

CODA is a beautiful film. I loved it and cannot recommend checking it out enough! I could easily see this winning best picture and I can't help but want to just rave about this film. I loved getting to peek inside the lives and challenges of a marginalized and often forgotten group. It's shows that the difficulties brought in by deafness are not only experienced by the deaf people themselves but also their family members, especially their children who can hear. It's a brilliant and heartfelt exploration of this as we follow Ruby, a young girl whose deaf family relies on her to help with their fishing business while she looks to pursue her love of music, something they can't truly get a sense of. I thought it was just excellent and I LOVED it. Sure, it's somewhat formulaic for the coming of age genre, but it's a truly radiant film, it's a deeply satisfying heart-warmer that embraces the pleasure and pureness of the formula, reminding one of the comforting and cathartic feelings of a feel good story that's well told. And that's exactly what this is. Emilia Jones is stunningly good in this movie and delivers what I think was one of the best performances this year. Not to mention her singing voice is gorgeous and she learned to both sing and sign for this role! The movie is just fantastic and it works so well as a comedy-drama, it's just exactly why it needs to be. Director Siân Heder did a perfect job, every aspect of this film excelled. It's simplistic, beautiful and delightful. I truly loved it. It's a must see masterpiece.I could very much see this taking Best Picture at the Oscars.
My title really says it all. Keep tissues close and prepare to watch a movie that speaks to all kinds of people. Really loved this film and highly recommend it!

This a wonder movie. I highly recommend this to everyone and I would like to see more movie like this being made. I am sure some will find some complaint, but I am not one of those people.Also, Tony Kotsur needs an Oscar!

reviews.review_title: ... it's good, but now have to find-watch the French version
reviews.content: ... family friendly to the utmost degree... story-script exactly what's to be expected... no more no less... cast all filling their roles admirably... based on the French comedy-drama La Famille Bélier from 2014... many reviewers indicating although they enjoyed CODA, La Famille Bélier was-is the better film... TBC.

CODA has everything that you could possibly want from a film.It is hilarious, eye opening, heartbreaking, and powerful throughout. The screenplay is incredibly clever and thoughtful, placing this unique perspective on the coming of age story which is executed so well.The performances are all amazing. Emilia Jones as the lead is incredible and deserved an Oscar nod in my opinion, but at least Troy Kotsur rightfully received his nomination.Sian Heder's direction is flawless. She navigates this subject in such a beautiful way, enriching the story and the family in a way that only the best directors can.The beauty of films and why I love movies so much is that they make us feel things, and CODA will make you feel everything. Not a second passes by where you won't be smiling, laughing, or crying. A truly stunning film.

I'm a CODA myself and could relate to Ruby so many times... We're the deaf characters portrayed a bit over the top? Yes! But I guess that's the only way to show people, that know nothing or just a bit about deaf culture, how different it is from the hearing culture... It was a heartwarming movie and I cried a few times ;) Definitely worth the watch! Will watch it again!

reviews.review_title: Pulled Me In And Made Me Fall In Love
reviews.content: I'm a guy who usually watches sci-fi and action movies so this film was not what I would normally watch. I won't give away the plot - plenty of others will do that! :) Instead what I will say is the story sucked me in from beginning to the end, I fell in love with the whole family (and Mr V - you'll see), I loved the music, it brought me to tears - more than once - and I was left satisfied at the end because I had an EXPERIENCE. A very rare 10/10 from me.

reviews.review_title: Every Few Years A Great Movie Comes Along! This Is That Movie!
reviews.content: Exceptional Cast with great timing. Stunning scenarios with life lesson monologues that open doors to the heart. Emilia Jones voice will awaken any sealed tear duct. This Movie is definitely Award worthy!
Some scenes in the last half had me in tears. Especially one scene with the daughter and dad sitting on the back of their pickup at night. Great film.

This is a remake/adaption of a french movie La Famille Bélier (2014),
That film hit some flak because some of the cast members playing deaf characters were not actually real life deaf, which kind of ignores the concept of acting. Hopefully every screen murder isn't an actual murderer.The film had a solid ace up its sleeve with Emilia Jones, she plays a convincing commercial fisher (I'm assuming she's not actually a full time fishing boat worker?) and a great example of a family member willingly and happily pulling more than her share of the family load. She's a very likable and relatible character and made the movie fun and pleasant to watch.For an adaptation they dumbed down quite a few plot details to make sure even the slowest of us would get their hammered home points, working against the insight and spryness of the greater movie.This wasn't the best film of 2021, it certainly had some good attributes, but the hokum script telling predictable stories detracted from the many good parts of it.

reviews.review_title: "a story that will resonate with many people"
reviews.content: CODA's main focus is on Emilia Jones' character Ruby, a child who loves to sing but whose family is deaf and relies heavily on her interpretation to keep their business afloat. This film shows the struggles of balancing family loyalty and expectations, whilst pursuing personal aspirations. Most importantly this story depicts a family that loves each other but whose actions communication do not always show it; I believe it's a story that will resonate with many people. CODA is a film of pure emotion, it has the ability to bring the audience to uncontrollable laughter, and tears of Joy, it was an emotional ride that I did not want to get off.

reviews.review_title: Beautiful, alive, soulful, fun everything that Sound of metal needed
reviews.content: They should take notes. It was well made, directed. A bit fantasyish about some situations, but it was easy to get by, the story was worthy of not mentioning them long. The nominations were well deserved, I haven't seen all the supporting actors performances yet, but I believe he has a good chance of winning. It misses the sound department nomination and best song and director, but for start, the original nominations are on point. Well done Apple! Keep surprising us.

This is probably the most emotional film I've seen all year. The feelings come hard and fast here and the story ends up packing a punch for even the toughest of viewers. It's nice to see some underrepresented topics and people covered in this story. Yes, it's not hard to see where the film is going, but that doesn't make it any less impactful.I really enjoyed this movie and I think anyone who wants to see some unfiltered emotion delivered through deft storytelling should check it out.

Saw this movie at SUNDANCE 2021. Features great performances all around, but Emilia Jones is going to be a star. Would be awesome to see Troy Katsur get some recognition come awards season as well. The movie is full of heart, made me laugh and made me cry. There were some really beautiful scenes in here and some surprisingly funny ones. The only thing that holds it back is the predictability that comes with abiding by coming of age genre conventions. The pacing also drags a little bit in the middle of the movie. However, the family dynamic here just completely elevates it above normal coming of age fare.

reviews.review_title: One of the most beautiful films of the year.
reviews.content: One of the most beautiful films of the year. Feel good at it's best. Once you start watching you can't stop, especially when the lead actress is so cute that you can't take your eyes out of her. Beautiful visuals and innocent characters adds to the elegance of the movie.
What and amazing movie all of the actors did well and loved the movie it was amazing, I laughed, cried at the end made my heart frozen.Wishing to see more movies like this..
From beginning to end this was PERFECT! Not much to say, the singing, the acting, the storyline. So heartwarming, entertaining, huge win for apple tv!

A young teenage girl, Ruby Rossi (Emilia Jones), juggles between supporting her deaf family (Troy Kotsur, Marlee Matlin, and Daniel Durant) and her aspirations of becoming a singer.I loved this movie. It's not a "knock-your-socks-off" type of production, but I felt that all of the family members had real chemistry and I adored some of the moments where challenges were overcome. I particularly loved the performances of Troy Katsur as the father, Frank, and also that of Eugenio Derbez as Ruby's music teacher, Mr. V.It's very touching and heartwarming. I love it when there is a movie that seems like an average family drama but with a unique twist. The fact that this movie addresses deafness in a serious way while also giving a lot of charming and funny moments in the midst of miscommunication.A fun little movie that I found immensely enjoyable and will love to see more of these smaller indie films win higher level accolades in the future. This is the type of cinema that I'm really gravitating to more and more as they are more keen on telling unique and interesting stories that broaden my perspective on things.

My wife and I really enjoyed this. Characters you care about, a good story, interesting themes and not silly. Excellent and the best film/TV we've seen in ages. Wish there were more like this (and less stupid superheroes nonsense!)
I thought it was great. Definitely heart warming. I probably cried at least 6 times lol. I watched several of the movies nominated for best film. CODA was definitely my favorite. 8 stars.

reviews.review_title: "If we're kicking you out, we're doing it as a family!"
reviews.content: I haven't seen a film in a long time that takes you in so many different directions emotionally as "CODA". It brings a smile to your face while it brings a tear to your eye, and by that, I don't mean that it's a sad story. It's just that the situations are so heartfelt and moving, and poignant in a way that strikes at what it means to be part of a family. While the story of Ruby Rossi (Emilia Jones) is wrapped in a fairly formulaic plot line, it's her relationship and confrontations with father Frank (Troy Kotsur), Mom Jackie (Marlee Matlin), and brother Leo (Daniel Durant) that resonate with each conversation and outburst. Particularly moving is when after the school concert, Frank asks Ruby to sing the song for him. Damn, that scene really got to me. And what can you say about Ruby's rendition of 'Both Sides Now' at the finale? It encapsulated what the film was all about in a nutshell with an instructive message for anyone watching. But I have to end this review on a somewhat humorous note with a mention of Best Supporting Oscar Winner Troy Kutsur, who's appearance closely resembled a long time acquaintance and friend of mine who lives in my hometown. It might not have made such an impression, except for the fact that in the picture, Kotsur portrayed a fisherman, and the guy I'm talking about is named John Fish!
Give & take, love & understanding is what it's all about. Great movie, when is the sequel coming? 😬

I don't usually prefer films like this, let's say small dramas that don't have a fast tempo, but I really liked this one. The reason probably lies in the reality of the characters, but also in the direction in which the film developed. The reality is that the deaf people in the film are played by actors who are deaf in real life, so it was easier for us to convey and show us the situations in which deaf people find themselves every day.The main character is a teenager Ruby who faces a very difficult choice: to follow her own path and dreams or stay with a family that depends a lot on her as she is the only member of that family who is not deaf. The moral dilemma seems real and I feel sorry for Ruby who is torn between those two paths. There's not a single boring scene in the film, and the drama is shattered by a couple of scenes that contain a bit of humor.The film invites us and shows us how to be aware of the problems of the deaf because the things we take for granted cause them a big problem in life and this is very nicely shown in the film without any pathos or regret. It all looks very real, real people with the right relationships and feelings. That, in my opinion, is perhaps the strongest aspect of the film.

I'm a musician so this got somewhat deeper I me. All was going great until she started singing in front of her family. That was it for me. Couldn't stop crying until the end of the movie. Goes immediately on my #1 beating Green Mile, Midnight Express, A Separation and Lala Land. THANK YOU GUYS.

Ruby Rossi is a child of deaf adults (CODA) though has hearing herself. In addition her only sibling, her brother, is also deaf. She is her family's sign-language interpreter and helps out on the fishing boat. In her final year of high school she shows great talent as a singer and has applied to attend Berklee College in Boston. Where will this leave the family?A sweet, feel-good movie, winner of Best Picture at the 2022 Oscars. Has a very original setting - a hearing child whose entire family is deaf - and the movie shows how this presents certain challenges and unique situations.A light-hearted feel to proceedings keeps things moving along briskly. Emotional ending rounds things off nicely.However, does feel quite formulaic. While the setting is original, the plot is fairly predictable and lightweight, sometimes having the feel of a midday TV movie or teen rom-com.Overall, not brilliant but worth watching.

I watch movies for the escape but sometimes one shows up that's grounding . This story could have been told a thousand ways and there are as many CODA's as there are versions. It's not about that anyway , really . It's it's own rhythm. It's a story told from the perspective of one family member yet we come to understand the family itself and each's desires and needs . It's highly relatable and actually quite lovely. It's as solid an eight if there ever was one. I gave it a nine because it stayed with me the next day, heck it's with me right now. This is that film .The cast is exceptional , the setting familiar , the simplicity coupled with its highly effective direction and production .No wonder it's up for an Oscar.

In 2008, "the HURT LOCKER" won the Oscar for best movie. Until "CODA," they have been on a long dry spell. Best movie of the year seems about right. Great story of song and family and love. We enjoyed it very much!

reviews.review_title: A child of a deaf adult becomes a modern staple of movies
reviews.content: CODA (2021)3.5/4'CODA' is a warm, fuzzy welcome into the time of a misrepresented culture in film - deafness. I don't believe that there is any better film to introduce a person to it. The movie follows a teenage girl, Ruby (Emilia Jones), the daughter of two deaf adults (Marlee Matlin and Troy Katsur), and her older sibling Leo (Daniel Durant), as the girl struggles to juggle her family business with her passion, singing. She loves to sing, much to her parent's dismay.It's truly a wonderful and heartwarming experience to see her overcome all these roadblocks. I have one problem with the film though, and that involves the story. It's a bit too sappy, and almost a little too predictable. It's a movie that you walk into expecting something and getting just that. A 'tearjerker' as they used to say in the 1950's. If a film like this has just one flaw, it's a very admirable piece of work - I loved it, and would easily recommend it.Note: Troy Katsur won best supporting actor for his work here, and he couldn't have deserved it more. He was fantastic. This film also won best picture, which I completely agree with. (CODA was my number two pick; I chose Licorice Pizza as my favorite nominee; but that had no chance of being able to win). It may have been a disastrous Oscar night, but the awards given here were absolutely deserved; I would only say however that I would have also liked to see Marlee Matlin win a second Oscar for her work here.

Every once in a while, a film comes along and unexpectedly pulls at the heartstrings in a feel-good way. 'Coda' is the latest example of this.The Gloucseter, MA-set "little film that could" has quietly gained ground in this year's Oscars race as it continues to reach a wider audience through Apple TV+. What the film lacks in starpower (save a perfectly cast Marlee Matlin), it makes up for it in everything else. From the touching coming-of-age story of a young woman at a crossroads of choosing between supporting her deaf family and pursuing her passion for singing to its perfect mix of offbeat humor and serious subject matter, 'Coda' illuminates the challenges faced by the deaf community in a respectful and engaging way.There are a few scenes in 'Coda' where it's almost impossible not to reach for a tissue - this is the mark of a movie that strikes a chord with its audience. Not only does Emilia Jones have a bright future in acting, but her angelic voice will take her equally far. And the Rossi family patriarch (played by Troy Kotsur) is a portrait of a complex, tough yet compassionate man who perfectly represents the Massachusetts fishing community.'Coda' is the rare breed of a triple threat film that has the potential to educate people while making an emotional connection and still managing to be entertaining.

This film should have been one of the big talking points of the Academy Awards the year it won Best Picture, unfortunately the world was instead talking about Will Smith hitting Chris Rock, however it was recognised throughout Awards Season, and I was looking forward to watching it. Basically, in Gloucester, Massachusetts, Ruby Rossi (BAFTA nominated Emilia Jones) is the child of deaf adults (CODA), the only hearing member of her family. Her parents, Frank (Oscar and BAFTA winning, and Golden Globe nominated Troy Kotsur) and Jackie (Marlee Matlin), and older brother Leo (Daniel Durant), are all deaf, and all communicate through American Sign Language. Ruby assists with the family fishing business and after graduating from high school plans to go into it full-time. In her spare time, she enjoys listening to music and singing. Because of her family, Ruby is an outcast at school. Ruby has a crush on fellow student Miles (Ferdia Walsh-Peelo). She notices him signing up for choir, and impulsively does the same. Her best friend Gertie (Amy Forsyth) worries that this could lead to bullying. One day, Ruby accompanies her parents to a medical appointment where a Doctor (Jason Pugatch) confirms they have "jock itch", a fungal infection most common when spending time in damp clothes (from fishing). The doctor says it is transferrable through intercourse and recommends Frank and Jackie abstain from sex for two weeks. On the first day of choir, teacher Bernardo "Mr. V" Villalobos (Eugenio Derbez), instructs the students to sing "Happy Birthday to You" to determine their vocal ability and assign their parts. Faced with having to sing in front of the class, Ruby panics and runs away. She later returns to Mr. V and explains that she was bullied as a child for talking differently. Mr. V tells Ruby there is room for all kinds of voices in the choir and is surprised and impressed by her beautiful singing voice. Mr. V pairs Ruby with Miles for a duet at the upcoming choir recital. Their first rehearsal goes poorly as they have prepared separately; Mr. V insists that they must practice together. Ruby invites Miles to her house to practice, but they are interrupted by Frank and Jackie loudly having sex in the next room, ignoring the doctor's advice. Ruby later hears classmates in the cafeteria mocking the incident. Miles insists her he only told one person, who spread the story; angered she tells him he wants nothing to do with him. She eventually forgives him, and they resume their practice while forming a relationship. Meanwhile, Frank and Leo struggle to make ends meet with the fishing business as new fees and sanctions are imposed by the local board. At a board meeting, everyone is angry that more boats are disappearing from the harbour even though the counsel is trying to help. During the yelling Frank stands, interpreted through Ruby, he announces that he is going to start his own company and intends to sell his own fish, inviting other local anglers to join him. The family struggles to get the new business off the ground, relying on Ruby to spread the word. Mr. V encourages Ruby to audition for Berklee College of Music. He offers to help her prepare with private lessons, as he is already privately tutoring Miles. Ruby agrees, but her increasing commitments to the family business, with her parents dependent upon her interpreting for them, cause her to be late for their lessons. Mr. V grows impatient with Ruby's constant lateness and berates her for wasting his time and not caring enough about music. One day, while Frank and Leo are fishing, they have a federal fishing observer on board, who was unaware in advance that Frank and Leo are deaf. Meanwhile, Ruby is out swimming with Miles at a lake. Frank and Leo's boat is intercepted by the Coast Guard, after they failed to respond to ship horns and radio calls. They are fined and have their fishing licenses suspended for negligence. They chastise Ruby for not being there when they needed her, she insists she can't always interpret for them, and this was not her fault. Frank and Leo appeal and successfully get their license back, on the condition that they always have a hearing person on board. Ruby announces to her family that she is giving up college and will join the business full-time. Frank and Jackie are supportive, but Leo is angry, insisting that they can manage without Ruby as she has talent. Leo and Ruby argue, with him telling her she would be wasting her opportunity and will regret not going to college. Ruby's family attends her choir recital, and while they cannot hear her sing, they notice the positive reception from the audience watching. Later that night, Frank asks Ruby to sing for him while he feels her vocal cords, and he gets emotional. The entire family then drives to Boston with Ruby for her Berklee audition. Before her audition, she sees Miles, who tells her that he failed at his audition and wishes her luck. Ruby is nervous and unprepared at first, but Mr. V comes to accompany her on piano. The auditions do not allow outside attendees, but Ruby's family sneak up to the balcony to watch her. Ruby starts deliberately, so Mr. V makes a deliberate mistake on the piano, allowing her to start again. As she sings, she gains confidence when she sees her family. Ruby signs along while singing "Both Sides, Now" by Joni Mitchell, so they can understand what she is singing. The adjudicators notice the family and realise the family situation. Sometime later, Ruby is accepted to Berklee. Her family and Mr. V are delighted with the news. She invites Miles to visit her in Boston. Meanwhile, the hearing workers in the family's fishing business can communicate with and interpret for the family after learning sign language. Ruby's friend Gertie drives her to Boston for college. They stop temporarily for Ruby to get out and give her family a hug, and she signs, "I love you so much" to them as they drive away. Also starring John Fiore as Tony Salgado, Lonnie Farmer as Arthur, Kevin Chapman as Brady, and Courtland Jones as Ms. Simon. Jones is splendid as the hearing teenage girl in a deaf family with a beautiful singing voice, Kotsur (who became the second and first male deaf Oscar winner) is fantastic as the girl's passionate father, Matlin (the first deaf Oscar winner) and Durant are great support as the mother and brother, and Derbez is likeable as the eccentric teacher. It is an emotional story about a teenage girl caught between helping her family's fledgling business and her ambitions to become a singer, and it makes you laugh with the banter between the family and some amusingly awkward moments, a great movie with heart and depth, a must-see compelling coming-of-age comedy-drama. It won the Oscar for Best Motion Picture of the Year (the first movie produced by a streaming service (Apple TV+) to win), and Best Adapted Screenplay for Sian Heder (also directing), it won the BAFTA for Best Adapted Screenplay, and it was nominated the Golden Globe for Best Motion Picture - Drama. Very good!

Oh yeah being deaf doesn't mean that you can't be horny.An Apple+ Original about a high school student who was the only hearing person in her family.I already love the movie when it started out. There were many funny and clever jokes mostly from the main character's deaf parents that showed the tight relationship in the family. I was consistently entertained with what our main character had to go through because she was the only hearing person in her family.This led to the main conflict for our main character. The struggle between family responsibilities and one's hope and dream was a familiar theme that is explored many times before. However, the story created a new and unique situation that had me sympathized with not our main character, but also her family members. The family dynamics worked so well that the situation even more conflicting.Still, the movie had many sweet moments. The audition scene near the end was beautiful and got me emotional there. Also, Emilia Jones, who played the main girl Ruby, had a beautiful voice, and I loved every scene where she sang.As for problems, the progression was definitely a bit formulaic, but it didn't bother me much at all.Overall, a sweet, beautiful, and unique slice of life/coming of age story. 9/10.

2021

director: Sian Heder
starring: Emilia Jones, Marlee Matlin, Troy Kutser, Daniel Durant, Amy Forsyth, Ferdia Walsh Peelo, Eugenio Derbez.As a CODA (child of deaf adults) Ruby (Emilia Jones) is the only hearing person in her deaf family. When the families fishing business is threatened, Ruby finds herself torn between pursuing her love for music and her fear of abandoning her parents. Wow what a truly moving and incredible film, I have so many amazing things to talk about here.My first few positives would be the amazing cinematography. The charming tone and humour. Excellent chemistry and performances from the cast. As well as the deep themes and excellent representation. This film was visually amazing. Not for its creative shots but for its beautiful simplicity, with long shots really highlighting the beautiful set locations of the film. The film had such a charming tone as well especially with its humour. None of it felt forced and it came across authentically, the family's interactions were so heartfelt and charming, and the awkward situations with Ruby's parents and Ruby and her brother offered a lot of great comedic moments. The whole family had such fantastic chemistry with each other, and it made the film seem so genuine and much more fun to watch. The whole cast also delivered excellent performances here. Everyone executed passionate, charismatic, and powerful performances showing a lot of versatility, specifically with Emilia Jones who was insanely impressive here. The themes that this film touched upon was also very moving. It tackled anxiety, fear of abandonment, responsibility, and the difficulties of having a disability so well and in so much depth it was amazing to watch. It was written so well and was often really moving to see. The representation for the deaf community this film gave was also amazing. It truly was done in a genuine and authentic way, highlighting the struggles the deaf community face, but also highlighting how they adapt and can live a normal life.My next few positives would be the soundtrack and music elements, the great character conflict and depth. As well as balance to the conflict. As well as the likeable main character and strong supporting cast with unique storytelling. The film did a really good job with its music elements. The Soundtrack was fun and Ruby or shall I say Emilia Jones had a beautiful voice and it was amazing to see her grow in confidence with her voice as the film developed. Ruby as a character was also just extremely likeable. I really connected to her character with her anxiety and social awkwardness, she got so used to people making fun of her due to her family it really knocked back her confidence. But as the film developed her confidence grew and so did my love for her character. She helped her family so much and sacrificed a lot for them. The character depth was some of the best I have seen. Each character had their own journey or things to grow on throughout the film. The son felt left out of the family and was finding his path into being accepted as a man. And the mother and father really grew in terms of their openness to see their daughter happy. Ruby as a character had a tremendous amount of depth, which is linked to the conflict. Her family have always been so reliant on her to interpret what other people say or to help with the business, in the process stopping Ruby from achieving her goals in life, and this film showed a great balance to both sides of the conflict and all the characters really grew from this conflict in terms of understanding each other. I also thought the supporting cast was very strong. Ferdia Peelo and Eugenio Derbez in particular. Eugenio Derbez delivered a charismatic performance; his character was so likeable. Despite a perhaps slightly harsh way of teaching occasionally he genuinely cares about his students and his chemistry with Ruby was a fantastic element to the film. Ferdia Peelo was also fantastic. The romance wasn't a big part of the film which I loved as it didn't need to be the main focus. But he delivered a charming performance and his romantic chemistry with Emilia was great to see. Finally, I loved the unique storytelling. This film really incorporated sign language into how the story was told which I loved. Often due to being with a deaf family Ruby expressed her emotions through sign even though she could speak, due to her confidence issues she found this the best way to communicate. It was such a clever and interesting way to incorporate sign language that felt fresh and unique to the film.My final few positives would be the uplifting moments, emotional weight and moving ending. This film was so uplifting and offered such a hopeful message about living with a disability and showing that you can learn and adapt to live a normal life. This film had so much emotional weight and really got to me. It was just heart-breaking to see the families struggles, they couldn't enjoy Ruby's singing because they couldn't hear it and the personal scenes between Ruby and her parents really touched me. This movie handled its deep themes and really showed what it's like to be deaf, and it has really stuck with me. The ending was so moving, the family were such a strong unit by the end, fully supporting Ruby. And Ruby getting accepted into music school was so powerfully done, with her audition being sung and done in sign language at the same time. It was truly moving cinema.Overall, CODA is my favourite film of the year and completely deserved its win at Sundance. In a powerful, moving, and uplifting story. That was incredibly written. Filled with incredible performances and it really moved me emotionally. Offering so many beautiful messages about love, acceptance, and family. Giving important representation to the deaf community showing that with hard work, determination, and cooperation with the people around you, people with disabilities are just as capable at living a normal life.Overall rating 100/100.

"CODA" is a beautiful looking, beautifully acted, emotionally draining movie. The last hour had me tearing up like you wouldn't believe. Everything about this movie works. I plan on watching "CODA" again real soon.

Really beautiful film that had me in tears at the end. Exceptional performances from the four lead actors Emilia Jones, Troy Kotsur, Marlee Matlin and Daniel Durant! Jones does her own singing with a rich melodic tone that draws you in. Seriously think the Academy should have given her a nod for best actress in her heart wrenching performance dealing with the pressure of being the only hearing meme we her family which was thought was stronger than Kristen Stewart and Nicole Kidman's nominated performances.
My sister had autism and she can't speak, so in the whole movie i'm thinking about her and my family, and i was so emotional the whole time, thanks for everyone who worked on this movie.

"CODA" is an endearing and moving story about the reality of deaf parents and their hearing children, told from the perspective of the teenage daughter. The script is endearing, moving, and masterfully written. The performances of the entire cast are fantastic: Emilia Jones is an amazing actress and her performance is deep and bold, Eugenio Derbez gives an incredible performance mixing drama and comedic overtones, the best of his career, Marlee Matlin is a tremendous actress and her character is completely realistic, Troy Kotsur offers a scathing performance, the most successful of the cast, Daniel Durant has an excellent acting level that nurtures his character with nuances, Ferdia Walsh-Peelo shows his talent and is obviously a great young promise in the world of cinema, and Amy Forsyth plays the most complex character of her career, a wonderful young actress with a great future. Sian Heder's direction is powerful, the music score is incredible, the soundtrack is beautiful, the sound design brings you into the picture, the cinemastography is vivid and elegant. "CODA" is a moving masterpiece!
I laughed, I cried. This movie is just beautiful...I rarely give a 10 star rating but this movie deserves it and I highly recommend it. People who give it a 1 star rating don't have a soul...

CODA is a film full of heart and love. The movie takes us on a journey with loveable characters and high felt emotions. This movie is so real and it makes you feel how all movies should. Laughter, tears, joy, pain. Led by Emilia Jones who kills it and is definitely in Oscars contention. CODA is a brilliant watch and will make youre day a little bit better.

reviews.review_title: Almost as Good as Belfast - CODA
reviews.content: The screenplay and direction of Sian Heder is equal to that of Kenneth Branagh for Belfast in every way, and a good case could be made for a tie for Best Screenplay. The same could be said for Best Picture; a tie in my book between Belfast and CODA. Child of Deaf Adults would have been a lesser title; CODA was the right choice. Emilia Jones was almost as good as Nicole Kidder in Being the Ricardos, and deserved a nomination for Best Actress.The only minor weakness of the film is the predictable ending; something not present in Belfast. We already know how things will turn out, especially since the girlfriend of her brother can hear and speak. Despite that minor flaw, the film is brilliant, and the performances of the entire cast are outstanding. There is one segment in the film that is unforgettable; when the viewing audience actually experiences what it is like to be deaf, while everyone else is having a good time. Good to see Marlee Matlin again; the first big role since Children of a Lesser God made 35 years ago. A movie not to be missed.

reviews.review_title: Extraordinary higher delight and work of art loaded with passion... Marked for life... 11/10
reviews.content: Unfortunatelly I'm gonna stay short in terms of review, since they never pass, I have kind of hard language so I don't want to find myself again with only wasted time...But I really desire for this to pass, I wouldn't burry the thought of ignoring to rate this movie and text those few words of recommendations.I don't know how did they gathered this amazing people to complete this filming process, but literally every single actor/actress in this movie nailed the role, and Ruby and Bernardo chemistry on screen the way they complete each other and how teacher is pulling the inner strenght of voice from the student is heart melting, a virtuose duo.
