reviews.review_title: A fantastic and unique take on the "talented family member" trope.
reviews.content: Every once in a while, a movie comes along that's surprisingly unique. Like, you would have thought such a plot would have existed a dozen times already, but Hollywood has only remade it once from a version that was initially in French. CODA (2021) is such a film. Sure, it has elements that are common to other dramatic films-like fishers, singers, and family dynamics. The combination of these things makes CODA stand out as unique to me. Not only does its double-meaning title elevate it above other movies, but its heartfelt content is something we need more of in this depressing world.CODA's take on the "my family doesn't understand my talent and is holding me back" cliche hits differently in this scenario. It's not that Ruby (Emilia Jones) has a family that ignores her obvious talent for singing, it's that they literally cannot understand how much better she is at singing than the average person. Since she is the only one in their family fishing boat who can communicate with others at the docks, they have placed an over-reliance on her ability, which traps her in the tough position of supporting her family versus pursuing her talent.With so many movies focusing on broken families and people, CODA is a refreshing change of pace. Even with everyone else being deaf, Ruby loves her family, and they all love each other. Their struggle is not within their disability, but against the systems that attempt to hold them back. There's deep emotion in having to choose between your family and your obvious talent, and CODA does this incredibly well by pushing Ruby to make this choice at every twist and turn of the plot. Funny, charming, emotional, and wholesome, CODA is an instant classic.A fantastic and unique take on the "talented family member" trope, I give CODA 5.0 stars out of 5.

reviews.review_title: A funny, often touching story of a young lady, her future ambitions, and her tight-knit family
reviews.content: "CODA" is a comedy-drama based on the 2014 French film "La famille Bélier". Directed by Sian Heder and starring Emilia Jones, Troy Kotsur, and Marlee Matlin, it is a funny, often touching story of a young lady, her future ambitions, and her tight-knit family.In Massachusetts, high school student Ruby Rossi (Emilia Jones) helps out with her family's fishing business, planning to work for them full-time after graduation. Since Ruby is a "CODA" (Child Of Deaf Adults), she is required to assist her father Frank (Troy Kotsur), mother Jackie (Marlee Matlin), and older brother Leo (Daniel Durant), all three of whom are deaf, with anything important, communicating and translating for them in American Sign Language. As she approaches the end of her school life, Ruby decides to follow her passion for singing and so signs up for a choir class. Ruby's teacher Mr. Villalobos (Eugenio Derbez) sees potential in her but she soon discovers the difficulty in finding time to practice for an upcoming recital while her family is struggling to make ends meet without her.As I stated in my review for "Sound Of Metal", it is easy to take for granted something like our sense of hearing, considering how simple it is to listen in on our surroundings without a second thought. That movie helped open my eyes to how appreciative we should be to have that sense at our leisure when there are many out there who aren't so lucky. A similar thing happens here with the film "CODA", in that it makes you fully aware of how hard it must be to live with others who have this handicap, especially when the people in question are your own close family members.What could have been another generic coming-of-age story is instead a rather heartfelt tale of a young girl finding ways to create balance in her life. Ruby is shown to be someone who is constantly fighting an uphill battle being the only person in her family who can hear, necessitating her involvement in their fishing business, all while contemplating whether or not this is the future she really wants. On top of that, she is also an outcast at school where the other students tease her for being that weird girl who smells like fish and has a family who cannot communicate verbally like everyone else. Despite these issues, Ruby still loves her family unconditionally but it presents a serious dilemma for her, as she must decide between achieving her dream of becoming a singer or staying behind to help with the business. It is this ultimatum that provides an excellent driving force for the film's plot since it is made clear from the beginning that things could go either way.In addition to "Sound of Metal", another film this one reminded me of was 1993's "What's Eating Gilbert Grape". Both feature a young protagonist living in a small town who is busy tending to the needs of their unusual family while longing for a better life out in the real world. But most importantly, the two films each did a great job of humanising its characters with irregularities without reducing them to that of a circus freak show. In spite of their deafness, Ruby's parents are depicted as a loving couple that have had an enduring marriage throughout all of their hardships. Sure, they may not be able to hear anything and argue using only sign language, but their impassioned love for each other and their two children makes them seem like a more realistic husband and wife team than most others I've seen on screen.Although the film is primarily dramatic in tone, it isn't afraid to shy away from being comedic when necessary. I was surprised at how often I was laughing at some of the strange situations that occurred throughout the story. Many of these moments involved Ruby's family, mostly from her father Frank's misunderstanding of others trying to interpret his sign language. Ruby acts as the primary translator for her family and this means she often bares the brunt of others shooting the messenger even though she is only trying to help. Thankfully, whenever something funny occurred involving one of the deaf characters, it never felt like we were laughing at them but instead at the circumstances that led to this awkwardness in the first place.Also worth mentioning is that the film makes good use of its setting. Like "What's Eating Gilbert Grape", the small town where the film takes place uses a limited amount of locations like the family home, school classrooms, or a teacher's house. The only time the film feels more open is when we see the Rossi family sailing on their fishing boat with the wide ocean symbolising the outside world Ruby longs to see for herself. This use of smaller settings made the film seem like a low budget indie picture. I could easily imagine this being released in the early-to-mid 2000s, since that was the peak era of popularity for these types of films.Unfortunately, what tarnishes the film's small town charm is the overabundance of Apple product placement. As this film is an Apple TV+ exclusive, some parts feature inconveniently placed shots of characters using iPhones and MacBooks with particular emphasis on the Apple logo shoehorned into certain scenes. Though they aren't too frequent, these scenes did bother me as it makes the film seem more corporate than it should be. Normally, a character using commercial products in a film doesn't bother me, but this time it felt as though the filmmakers were going out of their way to make a point that every electronic product being used by someone was made by Apple.Each member of the cast played their roles perfectly, with Emilia Jones providing the heart and soul of the film as Ruby. Jones seamlessly fits in with her onscreen family, whose actors are actually deaf in real life, so much so that you really get the feeling that they are related. Reportedly, Jones also learned American Sign Language over the course of nine months in order to effectively communicate with them, using both her hand gestures and her speaking voice. It goes to show that the art of acting goes beyond simply memorising lines from a script and that body language also plays a key part in giving a convincing performance.Many of the film's warmest moments were thanks to the duel performances of both Troy Kotsur and Marlee Matlin as Frank and Jackie. There are some genuinely poignant moments involving their interactions with Ruby. One scene with Frank involved him cracking a "dad joke" to her at the dinner table in typical eye-rolling fashion, but what made it so nice to watch was how he does it all through sign language. This is to remind us that even though he can't speak to her through conventional means, he is still her father and wants her to know he loves her anyway. Another scene involved Jackie talking with Ruby about her birth and the importance of that day. Without going into too much detail, this was one of the most affecting scenes in the movie that further establishes them all as a close family. Although their scenes were brief, I also liked the sibling rivalry between Ruby and Leo. Even though Leo is the older of the two, he comes across as less mature due to his hearing difficulties affecting his self-confidence. From time to time, Ruby finds herself clashing with him over the smallest of things, and this provided some interesting bonus conflict that made the story more investing than it already is.Much like "Sound of Metal" before it, "CODA" has successfully demonstrated to its audience the difficulties that arise from living without one of your primary senses. This time, however, from a familial third person perspective rather than through the actual protagonist itself. Not only that, but it has done so in a respectable manner that never mocks its subjects or uses them for cheap entertainment. There's so much to enjoy in watching this family that don't let their physical impairments tear them apart and actually try to work through any problems constructively. It's rare to see this in films nowadays so such integrity cannot be overstated.I rate it a solid 9/10.

I enjoyed the family dynamics and the pressure on Ruby as the only hearing person in her family all she hears and feels that her family may not really know and her love of singing. Just beautifully done. A definite must see movie and Oscar buzz is well deserved. The music was amazing and really opened my eyes to the struggles others have in every day life.

After seeing this cinematic masterpiece,

reviews.review_title: I'm giving it a standing ovation right NOW!
reviews.content: I don't cry!! I don't cry!! I don't cry!! ... I cried. (...and laughed)Listen, I'm not some touchy, feely, sensitive guy. I like my Sci-Fi, Horror and Action movies. I especially do not like subtitles. Still, I felt drawn to this story when reading its description. Its fresh. Different.It didn't disappoint! Right from the start, Ruby's (Emilia) soulful voice grabs you and doesn't let you leave the room for a popcorn run. To think she took singing lessons (in addition to the sign-language and fishing lessons), and was able to perform like that made me believe that... maybe I could sing if I took lessons? Nahh... they probably don't have supernatural abilities.There was a scene with Ruby and her brother Leo (Daniel Durant) that I thought was amazing. The emotion. The pain, frustration and ... conflict of loving the person who is the antagonist to your position in the family was palpable. Well done Daniel!I am familiar with some of Marlee Matlin's (the Mom) work. Not much but I know she's done well with her career, but I didn't like her character in this film. They do some work to try to endear her character to the audience but it wasn't enough for me. At one point her character tried to convey a sense of the empty nester parent that I felt came across as self-centered and uncaring. I just couldn't with her after that. Maybe that's what they were going for.Troy (the Dad) was great also and offered up a welcome comedic relief and not in the form of some one-line chucklers but actually roared laugh that I am sure my neighbors heard.They could have developed the love interest a bit more. It felt thrown in at the last minute. I understand the movie was about the family and the dynamic of being a CODA. But then what value did the romance with Miles add to it. It felt like one of those unwritten rules where every movie has to end with the boy getting the girl (in this case vice versa).Still, this was all around a great movie!! The best I've seen in a long time. I'd pay to see this twice in a theater!!

reviews.review_title: An important representation for the people of the Deaf Community
reviews.content: "You know why God made farts smell? So deaf people could enjoy them too"Sian Heder's "CODA" is a modest, heartwarming coming of age tale that not only embodies a youngster's fascination for Music but also sheds some light on the community of deaf people in the most truthful way possible. By signing three real-world deaf performers, they made their intentions quite clear, they weren't here to mess around, they were aiming for perfection, and as much authenticity as feasible. And guess what? The entire ensemble poured their hearts out in here.Despite all the familiar tropes laying around and the narrative being pretty much on the predictable side; I did like their approach. They kept it relatively simple (Yet effective) with just the right proportion of light humour. Needless to say, the narration is very much to the point and strives to serve a particular purpose here, which is to speak on behalf of the deaf community and its people.While I do agree the film is entitled to all the love and appreciation coming on its way but to present them with the "Best Picture" award at the Oscars, is a decision that I'm still finding tough to comprehend. I mean, come on! Weren't there much better options to give this award to?Pardon me for the unwarranted cynicism here, but I had to get that off my chest. Ever since I have been made aware of the winners, it has been pretty difficult for me to accept the result.Don't get me wrong, I'm delighted for the deaf community, my heart goes to the deaf people who have always wanted to be an integral part of society, and their part of the stories need to come out in the open as well. And now it seems their prayers are finally being listened to and that too on a universal scale.

CODA is a great film. There is a lot of heart and charm to it. It's a fantastic coming of age story but also a deeply moving family drama. The central focus on family is where it hits the most and the cast does a stellar job at portraying the complex family dynamic. The whole cast shines throughout and are a great ensemble. One moment that really sticks out is an interaction between the daughter and her father at the end of the film. That was amazing and very moving, emotional, etc. All in all, this was a lovely film, I really enjoyed it.

This film was wonderful.Set in Boston on the waterfront.A girl who loves to sing is born to two deaf parents and a deaf brother. reviews.review_title: An Excellent Depiction Of The Conflicts On Not Being Able To Hear
reviews.content: I admit I was impressed by Troy Kotsur when he won the Best Supporting Actor Oscar at the Academy Awards. Marlee Matlin was there too rooting him on and I remember watching her win the Oscar for Best Actress back in the 1980s for Children Of A Lesser God. Back then and now, it elated me seeing those with hearing impairment given a chance to shine and prove their talents in the film industry. That's when I knew I had to check CODA out.After viewing it this afternoon, it did indeed live up to its expectations. It's an extremely touching story of a teenage girl with no hearing problems who acts as the anchor to her deaf parents and brother. She's always been the translator to them to communicate with the hearing world, but when she lands a crush on a boy at school and ultimately learns her singing talent, she comes to realize she needs to follow her own interests and dreams.That's where the problems begin. She gets torn between the dependency her deaf family has on her to what she really wants to eventually do in life. It's subject matter that's handled remarkably well and heightened by superb performances by the whole cast. It can be deeply hilarious and also deeply touching at the same time. It also brought a better understanding to what those with hearing impairment go through and their troubles in communicating with the hearing world.I only recall meeting a few deaf people in my life, but the one I never forgot was a dishwasher at a local diner in my home town. When I got hired there to be a dishwasher too, he was excellent in his silent communication on teaching me what to do. I didn't know sign language, but he broke that barrier by constantly pointing, nodding and shaking his head and showing me examples on how to do things on the job. I had no trouble understanding him at all and was deeply impressed by how well he could communicate without words.He didn't need any hearing family or friends available to be translators to what he had to say. He handled himself extremely well and I never forgot that. That experience and this movie did indeed provoke my interest in learning Sign Language. From what I've seen in this film, it is indeed an expressive way to communicate, especially when we are taught the "dirty words" and hilarious exchanges it can bring.So, hats off to Troy Kotsur, Marlee Matlin and especially Emilia Jones for their excellent performances in this coming of age film. Emilia especially shines with her excellent singing voice and the ability to confidently be the translator for her family while also juggling her schooling and fishing duties at the same time.I love this movie. I consider it one of the best recent films I ever saw and highly recommend it. It's not only great entertainment, but a learning experience as well. Nothing can ever match what this film has to offer. It's a true gem.

This movie gets 10 stars from me. I am in general a very harsh critic and it's rare for me to rate something 10 stars but this film deserves every one of those stars and probably more, too. It's a very moving, relatable story and the actors are all simply tremendous. I can't say enough good things about this film. I hope it wins all the awards it's nominated for.

IN A NUTSHELL:
As a CODA (child of deaf adults), Ruby is the only hearing person in her home. When she discovers a passion for singing, Ruby must choose between family fishing business obligations and her dreams to pursue music. After the film won the Grand Jury Prize and Audience Award winner at the Sundance Film Festival, Apple bought the distribution rights to it for $25 million, the largest sum at the time.CODA stands for "Child of Deaf Adults". The film is written and directed by Sian Heder. It has nothing to do with the 2020 movie also called Coda. This is an English-language remake of the 2014 French-language film called The Belier Family / La Famille Bélier - English Subtitles. It was filmed in Gloucester, Massachusetts.THINGS I LIKED:
Emilia Jones is a revelation. She acts, signs, and sings beautifully.Eugenio Derbez plays the passionate choir director. He's hilarious in everything he does, but he also shows a dramatic flair in his role since the film is more serious than a true comedy.I remember when Marlee Matlin first took Hollywood by storm when she won an Academy Award for Best Actress for her role in Children of a Lesser God, the only deaf actress to win the award. She has been deaf since she was a little girl.Actors Troy Kotsur and Daniel Durant are both deaf in real life.It's really powerful when you can't hear any sound and you get to experience what it might be like to be deaf. One of my nieces married a deaf man. Many members of my extended family, including myself, have been trying to learn sign language.There are some truly touching moments that made my eyes fill with tears several times. Very sweet.I like the title because it instantly intrigues you and you want to know what it's all about.THINGS I DIDN'T LIKE:
The story is sweet and touching and yet there is a lot of crude content that makes it inappropriate for family viewing, which is such a shame because there are some really great messages in the movie.TIPS FOR PARENTS:
Profanity - both spoken verbally and in sign language
Teenage girls talk about hooking up with guys.Adults talk about jock itch
You see a married couple doing it in bed (with clothes on)
The dad smokes marijuana.Men drink alcohol in a bar and get in a brawl.An underage teenager works as a bartender and explains that she can because none of the men there know how to count to 21.A lot of crude conversations and gestures.There's a lot of sign language spoken, obviously, so you have to read a lot of subtitles.You can see my full review on my Movie Review Mom YouTube channel.

I have no words, a great film!!!Emilia trained for learning sign Language and Singing for 9 months before shooting!Great performance by the whole cast. Everyone should see this film.Also, The winner of the best ensemble SAG Award! reviews.review_title: Emotional family drama of life, love, and communication.
reviews.content: Finally after these many months watched "CODA" just before it won best picture at the Oscars. And in a wild card subplot daughter Ruby(Emilia Jones) who helps work the fishing boats and sells and helps cook all kinds of fish while also on the side has a discovered talent of a singing music voice. reviews.review_title: not hard to figure out but still done very well
reviews.content: In a Massachusetts fishing community, teenager Ruby Rossi's life is anything but happy-go-lucky; she doesn't fit in at school, she really has no friends, and she's the only one who can hear in a deaf family of close-knit fishermen. Ruby's responsibility to her family continues to grow, but it hinders her from doing what she really loves: singing. The biggest criticism of this sincere, coming-of-age family drama is that the film's trajectory is easy to figure out early on, but that aside the journey is still a believable one, the emotional aspects are in check, and there's a terrific collection of actors in the cast led by Emilia Jones who's totally convincing, and a surprising amount of colorful humor courtesy of real-life deaf actor Troy Kotsur. ***

CODA is progress. The plot is formulaic, but it portrays an underrepresented community. Depicting complex deaf characters with legitimately deaf actors, CODA deserves recognition. Plus, the story has real obstacles, effective arcs, and touching conversations. Its convenient conclusion slightly undermines its conflicts, but the catharsis still feels earned. Ultimately, CODA displays atypical life in a world built for typical abilities, a poignant message. Furthermore, the acting elevates the material. Jones is wholly relatable, Derbez is eccentrically heartfelt, and Matlin, Kotsur, and Durant communicate various waves of nonverbal emotion. Thus, the script's shortcomings are outweighed by its dramatic impact.Meanwhile, CODA's filmmaking is above average. The cinematography uses attractive framing to convey significance, the editing utilizes intercutting during the climax, and the production design sets a humble tone. The soundtrack is an integral part of the narrative, heightening emotions and creating a nostalgic mood. Also, the sound design uses symbolic silence to show how deaf people can feel disconnected from the hearing community. Therefore, CODA might not be a technical masterclass, but it remains powerful for its meaningful use of relevant mediums. It isn't a perfect film, but CODA is clearly a valuable experience.Writing: 8/10
Direction: 8/10
Cinematography: 7/10
Acting: 9/10
Editing: 7/10
Sound: 9/10
Score/Soundtrack: 9/10
Production Design: 7/10
Casting: 9/10
Effects: 6/10Overall Score: 7.9/10.

reviews.review_title: Strong lead performance and heartfelt uplift
reviews.content: Ruby (Emilia Jones) is a high school senior living is the seaport town of Glouscester, just north of Boston. In addition to all the usual awkward teenager issues of her studies, boys and mean girls, Ruby has to get up at 3 am every day to help with her family fishing business. Oh, and her parents (Marlee Matlin, Troy Kotsur) and brother (Daniel Durant) are deaf (the entire movie is subtitled and close captioned).Writer-Director Sian Heder (adapting a French film, La Famille Belier) centers her movie on Ruby as a way for the audience to understand the family's dynamics. Her script also uses the Massachusetts setting to give it it's own specific feel and atmosphere and not feel like a rote remake. Heder is also smart in never trying to artificially present the clan as a "normal family", while always maintaining a sympathetic eye and ear towards them.Ruby has never been "good at school", but she shows some talent as a singer when she joins the school choir on whim. Eugenio Derbez plays her colorful music teacher (we first see him in an ascot) who encourages her talent. Derbez performance shows warmth and wit, and is able to escape caricature. Less successful is the humor which is often forced and too overly broadly played. Sure, it's, I suppose, comforting to know that deaf families can be just as wacky as any other brood, but, tonally, it doesn't quite blend with the pathos.Jones gives a sweetly determined performance that carries the movie over it's bumps and occasionally too conventional plotting. It's a strong performance that lifts not only the movie, but the other performances as well. Jones stands out, but, it's never showy. A young actress to keep an eye on.CODA, the winner of Sundance's top award (which lead to Apple paying $25M for its rights), occasionally falls into the trap of seeming to check off the usual Festival Award Winner attributes (why do all young persons seem to be involved in Music and the Arts?), but, fortunately, Jones and and the movie's uplift make it a worthwhile journey.

reviews.review_title: I loved CODA! Funny and Inspirational film about what it's like to be a Child of Deaf Parents
reviews.content: "CODA," a new film coming to theaters and streaming on AppleTV+ on August 13 was a delightful and inspirational movie about what it is like to be a CODA, Child of Deaf Adults.Ruby Rossi is just a normal teenage girl who loves to sing, and her family is anything but normal. As the youngest child of deaf adults, Ruby takes on many roles that many other children don't need to worry about. Her father and older brother are fishermen in Gloucester, Massachusetts. She joins them every morning before the sun rises and before school starts out on the water as a deck hand, and the only one who can listen for distress calls from the Coast Guard or warnings from the National Weather Service. When they bring in the catch, she helps negotiate a price for the fish they catch, making sure they aren't getting ripped off compared to other fishermen.From the docks she goes to school with other kids who don't know what it's like being the daughter of deaf parents. She lives in a world that she feels she doesn't belong, but in her senior year, Ruby decides to do something for herself for once. She auditions for the high school choir.Besides bringing awareness of what it might be like for deaf people around us, the film explores the interesting dynamics between the world of hearers and the deaf community. The film also delves into how the deaf parents might feel if a child wanted to do something that they couldn't enjoy or appreciate due to their deafness.The film is as much about pursuing a dream and gaining independence, as it is about inter-dependence in a family and supporting one another. There are so many powerful moments throughout the film as Ruby explores what it means to be independent as well as what it means to be a CODA. It is a human story about connection and love and being there for one another no matter what. It is also a story about letting go and releasing someone you love to live life to the fullest.I really loved this film and the story that it told. I feel like I gained new empathy and understanding for deaf people in my community. The film is funny and sweet, but also inspirational."CODA" was written and directed by Siân Heder. The film stars Emilia Jones as Ruby Rossi, Marlee Matlin and Troy Kotsur as Jackie and Frank Rossi, Daniel Durant as Leo Rossi, and Eugenio Derbez as Ruby's music teacher, Mr. Villalobos among others.

I'm a French Sign language user, fluently, for social business.So I've seen the original, and.. don't waste your time or money, he is like a spit on the French Deaf communauty.This one.. is so much respectfull, realistic (?).Deaf life in a little city in america is what you live in a big city in France..
So thank you for this one so beautifull movie.Merci à vous.

I like it a lot that i actually watched two times in a row. I haven't have watch any movie two times in a row in my live. I watched in Japanese dub & English dub.CODA is such a great story that i have many thoughts after watching. Ruby, the 17 yrs little girl was actually not confident with her voice don't believe she can sing, being born in the deaf family. When the little girl was lack of confident on her accent, it's the Latin Spanish accent singing techer Mr. V helped her on her self-confidence. It's not in the story but i could imagine from the line, the techer had a tough life and that was similar with what Ruby has gone throught.It's not a genios girl AGT kind of heart moving emotion, it's towards a little non confident YOU find your little confidence that you believe in yourself that you want to move on, in a little desperated world and push back from your surrounding.Although i know nothing about the deaf community, the little girl challenge is just a mirror of many of our day to day challenge.If you watched the movie, the highlight is at 1h26m. That open you eyes to the other side of the story. And i fully understand why i felt awkward few minutes earlier. A sincere and touching film that elegantly portrays the coming-of-age challenges of a talented but shy high school senior while at the same time masterfully illustrating how a deaf family relates with each other and their world.

What a wonderful, wholesome movie with some truly precious scenes.I'm deaf (I'm 29) and I honestly can't believe how underrepresented the Deaf are on TV so thank goodness for this beautiful film.People pity those with a 'disability', and there's this old fashioned notion that the Deaf are humourless, old and incapable. So unbelievably not true, and I'm so glad this movie demonstrates all of that.Thanks to the director for fighting hard to cast real deaf actors, they were incredible.My favourite film of the year.

7/10 - while I often really enjoy movies that are able to highlight communities that do not often get their fair share of time in the spotlight (in this case, children of deaf adults and the deaf community as a whole) and that is the strongest part of this film, but for me, this story lacked some of the magic that others found in it.

Wow, was amazed by this movie! It has everything, great music, love stories, politics, prejudice, discrimination, it's all in there.Enlightening, entertaining, and a good feel movie too.I thoroughly enjoyed it and I highly recommend it.

reviews.review_title: Now, That is a good film.
reviews.content: It has been a minute since I have enjoyed a great film. Film these days are either preachy or too artsy. But CODA tells a beautiful story about family, sacrifice and having a dream. The cast gives an amazing performance accompanied by great music and moments that makes audiences think about their own journey. This movies is the best I have seen in a long time.
Touching without being over melodramatic. Funny at moments without idiocy.The director seemed to transmit well the situation of deaf people.A simple but compelling story. Good job.

I am so glad I chose to watch this movie. A beautifully narrated story dedicated to Family, Love and Passion. Every character played by all the actors have done justice to the story. Director has defined there role ao well. I would love to see it winning at Oscars. Makes you realise the hardships of a person with disabilities. Watch it and Happy Realisation!!

We have all watched those movies that just follow the formula and paint by numbers. That is this movie. The high school dramas and family dynamics and unrealistic teachers combine for the perfect crescendo of emotion. And it works anyway. Because if you create complex characters, tell real stories, and elevate communities that have been ignored, the formula becomes...more than than the sum of its parts. It isn't perfect, but good luck not being moved.

reviews.review_title: Formulaic, Funny And Much That Elevates It Above Similar Films
reviews.content: I avoided this for a while, worried that it may be a clichéd sort of heartwarming, formulaic comedic drama that we've seen many times in the past. It is many of those things; it is also often genuinely funny and insightful. A film that breaks this many barriers and thus holds the level of significance it does should probably be a bit more than that, however. That most of the narrative beats of the film are entirely predictable is a shame, but it's also true that several good performances do elevate it to a degree. A brilliant use of sound dropping away in a music performance scene gives to hearing audience members the most profound moment of empathy in the film; there are other moments, and sequences that hit home in their own way. Emilia Jones' singing voice is something special too, it's not hard to see her career taking a distinctly musical direction from here on out. Ultimately it has more to recommend it than other similar films, and its heart is undoubtedly in a good place. But it also could, and perhaps should, have been more too.
Coda is the best 2021 movie for me. The plot is so simple yet heart warming.

reviews.review_title: A rare commodity, an excellent remake.
reviews.content: I normally avoid remakes like the plague and was dubious about watching this as the film it's based on, The Bélier Family is one of my favourite films. It's beautifully cast with great performances and tugs the heart strings like the original.The lead, Emilia Jones is wonderful and has a stunning voice. No wonder with her father Aled Jones.There are many scenes which have effectively been copied from the original but some aspects have been changed.I went along for the emotional ride in the end and loved it as much as the original. It's exactly what a film should be. You grow to love and care about the characters. It's so nice to see a film like this being made amongst all the Superhero franchise movies. Highly recommended.

I came into this movie with an idea of what I thought it may be like to be hearing impaired, but never have thought to consider the full scope. This is a very eye opening film as it brings up hurdles endured from both someone who is deaf, and also a circumstance where you can hear but you are raised by a deaf family. This is a coming of age film unlike any other one I have seen, it's very original and brings an awareness to a disability that is often underrepresented in movies. I have not seen the original, but the fact that they used actual deaf actors is a huge bonus for me. They really knocked it out in their performances. I would be a liar if I said I wasn't moved to tears at the end. Great watch, would recommend to anyone!

reviews.review_title: perfect counter-balance to the loud and stupid tentpoles
reviews.content: This is a very sweet, but not overly-saccharine, coming of age story about a hearing girl trying to get into Berklee Music school to pursue her passion for singing.The only catch is her fishing family can't understand her dream because, well, they're entirely deaf except for Ruby herself who acts as their interpreter.Along with a healthy dose of high-school fish out of water tropes, this is the perfect counterpoint of a Sundance indie to the loud, stupid and obnoxious summer tentpoles.The original French movie La Famille Bélier that it's based on is also worthy of a look afterwards.

Well, you think you know how this is going to end when you first start watching it, but nothing can prepare you for the emotional depth it takes you to. The cast is great as an ensemble; they work so well together, and it is beautifully directed. This is a great film for everyone, shows you the true meaning of family first and just being there for each other.

I was able to experience this film at the Texas Theatre's Drive-In in Dallas and it was a great time.The film itself is very genuine and satisfying.I recommend it for anyone and would say it will be remembered as one of the best of the year.

reviews.review_title: I am almost never a fan of American remakes of foreign films....

reviews.review_title: The talented singer and her deaf family
reviews.content: It has been a long time since a film this charming and inspiring came along, but now that it has, we can all be grateful. A film does not have to be original or cutting edge to be great. This is a homespun take on devotion to family and reaching for the stars. It's an old-fashioned story but there's nothing dated about its heart or integrity.Ruby, the only family member of the Rossi family who is not deaf, is a teenager, portrayed by an impressive Emilia Jones. This young woman finds her passion in singing and music, which seems odd coming from a family living in silence. We accompany this young woman balancing between supporting her family and their business on the one side and following her dreams on the other.Seeing a loving and caring family struggling in a world of the hearing is extremely touching, and this movie is really authentic as all deaf family members are portrayed by deaf actors, Marlee Matlin as the mother Jackie, Troy Kotsur as the father Frank and Daniel Durant as the older brother Leo of the Rossi family. The amazing and brilliant Eugenio Derbez as music teacher Bernardo Villalobos is fun to watch and has an incredible impact on Ruby to follow her passion. Jones' powerful singing voice and subtly fierce screen presence makes her an up-and-comer to watch.This movie is a must see for everyone - it's full of life, love, passion and giving an insight into a world which usually is out of our focus.

reviews.review_title: A fresh take on the coming-of-age story
reviews.content: CODA offers a sweet and original take on the coming-of-age story through the eyes of a hearing young woman with dreams of being a singer; her challenge is that the rest of her family is deaf, and she both feels responsible for them and fears leaving them behind.Structurally, it reminded me of Billy Elliot, another film about a child wanting to pursue a career in the arts that will inevitably separate them from their working-class family. And like Billy Elliot, it has enough humor and authenticity about the community it portrays to make its classic story arc feel satisfying and fresh.It's an emotional button-pusher, but the characters felt original and the specifics of the family dynamics were drawn beautifully, including the older brother character who got frustrated by his younger sister's role as "martyr" to the family. These kind of specifics, along with really solid acting, elevated the film from just being a "crowd-pleaser" into something more satisfying.

There is no movie without the desire to tell a story. Struggling fishing village, the only hearing member of the deaf family, hopes and dreams, loyalty to your own and natural desire for self-fulfillment. And there it is, this smart, funny and surprisingly touching little flick. Awakening true emotion without resorting to cheap schmaltz. Providing information without being overly PC and patronizing. Well-deserved Oscars.

It's about Emilia Jones, who lives with her fishing family in Gloucester in Massachusetts. Her father, mother and elder brother are all deaf, so it's been up to her since she was a toddler to be their ears and voice. Amidst family crises like being squeezed by the middlemen, she decides on a whim to try out for the high school choir. It turns out she has a real voice; choir master Eugenio Derbez tells her she can win a scholarship to Berklee in mythical Boston. Can she convince her family to believe in her dream when they can't even hear her, or will her duty to them overwhelm her ambitions?In other words, it's RATATOUILLE for tweens, with another message that "Not everyone can become a great artist; but a great artist can come from anywhere", albeit with more songs. It's decently written, pleasantly shot, well acted, and has enough raunchy jokes for adults not to be ashamed to have seen it. It is, in short, the sort of well made small movie that wins outsized applause because it shows that, like JOHNNY BELINDA, the deaf are just like you and me, except they have more sex. It's a nice little middle-brow movie of the sort that used to win the Oscar every three or four years, with a very affecting version of "Both Sides Now." A very nice way to spend a couple of hours.

Better than the original french movie La famille Bélier, coda tells the story of a deaf family with only one hearing member (its daughter), who has to deal with the fact that she must be their interpreter and only communication link to the hearing world.As happened with its predecessor, the film fails in the same places.By showing the deaf family more like dumb or simple minded rather than taking the chance to show the real problems and daily struggling they have to face a big opportunity is wasted. It is possible -and would have been a far more interesting movie - to make a comedy and yet show what being deaf means and its challenges.Departing from an interesting premise - a deaf family and their communication difficulties with the hearing ones -the film fails into a parody instead.Being this one of main flaws of the film it is either unbelievable -and somehow insulting- that any of the family members lack the ability to communicate with hearing people. A nice improvement from the French version was changing the brother role from being unsubstantial one to a more mature one (the brother-sister discussion about him being able to do her interpreter work is a point that should have been deeply developed).Several other things seem to be out of place (deaf father driving? -maybe in the USA)
The ending scene with daughter singing in front of their parents using hand sign language while she sings so her family can understand what she is singing about sure is a nice one -by the way, the original lyrics in the French version were changed since they were not about leaving home for good but a farewell note from a kid who is going to commit suicide) but I rather much prefer the scene where she is singing at the school festival and her family has gone to watch to her.All of a sudden sound is off and we can have a terrifying glimpse of what being deaf really mean. To hear no sound. Any sound. Only watch her moving her lips. In the end other people applause. No sound at all. That IS what really means being deaf. That was for me the best and most emotional scene of the movie. Really goose feather.

reviews.review_title: Formulaic and predictable, yet touching in the best way
reviews.content: I discovered CODA by pure chance, without knowing anything about it. And a few days later CODA won the Oscar for Best Picture :)The original French film is also very nice, but the American remake suited me a bit more. Apart from the deaf family, CODA doesn't bring anything new to the table and it is a pretty formulaic feel-good "follow your dreams" film. However, CODA uses this formula perfectly - the film is emotionally moving in the right way and at the right moments, the humour is great, the characters are all likable, the cast does a great job, led by the excellent Emilia Jones, whose performance of 'Both Sides Now pleasantly surprised me.So allthough I'm not blown away overall by CODA, it definitely deserves higher rating.

I am a film completionist, meaning I must see a film through to the end no matter what. At times, I take a break and come back to it (figuring I might not have been in the right mood for the film) but in other times, I fight through whatever emotion I am feeling (most of the time boredom) to keep focused on what the filmmakers are attempting to do in their film - and, at times, I am rewarded for this perseverance.Such is the case with the Oscar Nominated film CODA. Written and Directed by Sian Heder (who was Oscar Nominated for her Screenplay), CODA tells the tale of Ruby who is a CODA (Child of Deaf Adults), who runs afoul of her family (especially her parents) and their expectations of her.For the first half of this film it is pretty standard fare - one that has been shown on many, many movie screens throughout the years. Even though this one had the added "plot twist" of Ruby being able to hear while her Parents and Brothers are all deaf, the first half of this film never rose above the ordinary.But, something happened in the 2nd half of the film, I fell in love with this family and their foibles and was rooting for them all to resolve their issues and for Ruby to get what she wanted.Credit for this must go to Writer/Director Heder, who is not deaf, who came up with the idea/concept for the film and then felt a strong obligation to "get it right" for the deaf community. And get it right she does.Her first good move was to cast Oscar Winner Marlee Matlin, a well known deaf performer and advocate for the Deaf Community. She brought instant credibility and star power to this film and she also insisted that the other 2 deaf characters in this film be performed by deaf performers.Troy Kotsur is Oscar Nominated as Best Supporting Actor for his turn as Ruby's father and he, for the first 1/2 of this film, acts in black and white - either funny (the comic relief) or angry (the drama) and I was unimpressed by him, but - just like the film - his performance gains some nuance in the 2nd half and he does have the "Oscar Moment" in this part of the movie that makes him a deserving nominee.Emilia Jones is "just fine" in the lead role of Ruby and Daniel Durant (the other deaf actor in this film who plays her brother) and Lonnie Farmer (who plays her teacher) are also "fine". Thank goodness we had the star wattage of Matlin to elevate the first half of the film before things got interesting - and nuanced - in the 2nd half.Kudos to CODA for shining a light on a group that does not normally get the light shone upon it and kudos to the Academy for nominating this Sundance darling in the Best Picture category.Letter Grade: B7 stars (out of 10) and you can take that to the Bank(ofMarquis)

reviews.review_title: Coda (2021, Sian Heder) Heartfelt film that evokes all the feels and while not dramatically weighty does not feel lessened by it
reviews.content: 'Coda' is an English language remake of the 2014 Belgian film 'La Familie Belier'. It stars Emilia Jones and, as the title indicates, she is the child of deaf adults although taking it one step further, in her family of four, she is the only hearing person as her older brother is also deaf. This is a coming-of-age drama/comedy directed by Sian Heder who's only other directorial achievement of note is 2015's 'Tallulah'. After 'Coda' debuted at Sundance the rights were purchased by Apple for $25 million. At the 94th Academy Awards 'Coda' was nominated for three awards and it won all three for Best Picture, Adapted Screenplay and Troy Kotsur won for Best Supporting Actor.In Gloucester, MA we are introduced to family of fishermen including teenage daughter Ruby Rossi. The distinction of this family that drives the entire plot is that the parents played by Troy Kotsur and Marlee Matlin as well as older brother Leo, played by Daniel Durant, are all deaf leaving Ruby as the sole hearing member of the family. Not only is she trying to navigate her tumultuous teenage years at her local high school she is also integral to the family's business as she does all the interpreting for the family when they have to interact with hearing folks which is essentially all the time. At the outset there is a feeling that the family is somewhat of an outcast clan due to their inability or unwillingness to communicate with the rest of their community. This ostracizing extends to Ruby who is chided at school not only because of her deaf family, but also because she is from a fishing family. Chasing a boy she signs up for choir, and we find out, despite some nerves, she is an amazing singer and at the behest of a fabulous teacher, played wonderfully by Eugenio Derbez, she begins to work toward a path of higher education in music. This causes a rift in the family as they do not understand her love of music thinking it might be just adolescent rebellion, but also without her they would lose their prime conduit to interact with the world at large. Things become amplified as issues occur with the business of fishing and regulations for the family which greatly effects Ruby's decision making process. There is also a young love story which is sweet, but not very dynamic as far as the story goes. 'Coda' goes the route of feel good movie and in the end many of the storylines are progressed to a satisfactory point looking forward toward a hopeful future for Ruby and the family in general.'Coda' was a bit of an upset win for Best Picture. By far the best reviewed film and the frontrunner was 'The Power of the Dog' which is a far more hefty, dramatic film with darker themes. 'Coda' is in the same realm as 'Green Book' in the pantheon of Best Picture winners. It does have some heavier themes, but it puts a positive, hopeful spin on all of its messaging. With a society still crawling up out of a pandemic quagmire perhaps the general feeling is that rewarding a film that is of a very high quality, but leaves you with good vibes and good feelings is more attractive than awarding a better film that is heavier and darker in its themes. To be clear I liked 'Coda' quite a lot and in fact out of the collection of Best Picture nominees it is second only to 'The Power of the Dog', but it certainly is not without its narrative flaws. There are story issues regarding the family's functioning and the fishing business operation at the end that aren't really resolved. It is more like everyone hugs at the end and lives happily ever after. It is not quite that idyllic but it is not far off, and while those positive sentiments are laudable they are not that realistic. You can have the happy endings, but in this instance I wish they would have done more to explain the nuts and bolts of their happy ending rather than just sort of saying it is a happy ending. To film's credit this is the movie that made me feel the most while watching it this year. It gives you such a rush of emotion that is commendable and hard to ignore, and it is that evocation that really sets this film above more standard fare telling similarly feel good stories.Eric's Grade: B+
