CODA is a heart-warming and feel-good movie that will leave audiences both crying and laughing. It follows the story of Ruby, a deaf teenager who is the only hearing member of her family. While she loves them dearly, she feels like an outsider in her own home and longs for a life outside of their small town. When she falls in love with a hearing boy and starts to pursue her dreams of becoming a singer, she must decide between the life she wants and the family that she loves.CODA is an uplifting story about following your dreams and being true to yourself. It features amazing performances from its cast, particularly Emilia Jones as Ruby who spent nine months learning American Sign Language to play her role. The film is beautifully shot and captures the stunning landscapes of Cape Cod. It's an emotional and feel-good movie that will stay with you long after the credits have rolled.

reviews.review_title: It was a feel good movie but Best Picture??
reviews.content: This just didn't have the polish of typical Oscar winners. I suspected that if they only had 5 nominations like most years past, this wouldn't have even been nominated.Don't get me wrong, the scene from her deaf parents perspective at the concern was very sad for me as a musician, very moving for her dad to try to feel her sing at the end, but there were a handful of parts that felt more like "deleted scenes" you might see "bonus feature" but totally agree they weren't needed scenes. The acting just wasn't that great (beyond the parents), the whole shy singer turn star felt cliché, the student/teacher relationship was predictable, she happens to hit it off with her cute duet partner, etc.Power of the Dog wasn't my favorite either but it had that polish, suspense, tension, strong characters and acting that we have seen win Best Picture year after year. West Side Story had all those elements as well. This one had none of that. Maybe there was just a split of votes that happen to fall in Coda's favor? Do they need rank choice voting because I can't imagine Coda getting over half of the votes.I'm a big Apple TV+ as well. I'm a musician. I have empathy for the main character but still.

CODA which stands for Child Of Deaf Adult directed by Sian Heder is a movie about a girl named Ruby Rossi played by Emilia Jones who is a hearing girl in a deaf family who wants to pursue her passion of singing but when her family needs her to help in their fishing business, now Ruby has to struggle between choosing her passion of singing or help her family with their business. Most movies that have to do with high school life and a struggle are usually really bad movies and end up cheesy but this movie is just phenomenal and I can't stop thinking about this movie, some of my thoughts on the performances throughout the movie is Emilia Jones can play a tough, strong, and shy girl who is struggling to fit in because of her situation she is in being the only hearing person in her family who is deaf and she plays a person that can't fit in. The Scenes in CODA was nicely shot for example when Ruby was alone singing at the lake, the cinematography is pretty good. The chemistry between all the Characters have together is really amazing, The acting in the movie is just like if they were in real life as a family, or in a school. I was impressed during these scenes where Ruby and Miles played by Ferdia Walsh Peelo were singing in a duet for the first time ever Ruby keeps looking at Miles showing how much she is into him but Miles at this point isn't really into her and keeps looking at Bernardo played by Eugenio Derbez which I think this is a really good scene. Another scene I liked is when Ruby is trying to explain how she feels to sing to Bernardo but can't put it into words so she signs how she feels to sing to Bernardo, he can't understand what she is signing but he can understand that it makes her feel safe and comfortable. Also another scene I liked is When Ruby and Miles are singing at the concert Frank Rossi played by Trot Kotsur and Jackie Rossi played by Marlee Matlin are looking around to see the audiences reaction to their daughter singing at they see that people are enjoying their singing and some tearing up to their singing and at that moment they realize that their daughter has real talent, also Ruby explains to her Frank that the song that she was singing at the concert was about what it is to need another person which perfectly shows what the parents are in need of, they need Ruby. This Movie has little to no flaws and I really enjoyed CODA and I will give this movie a 10/10, the next time Sian Heder makes a movie if its anything like this I will surely watch it.

Takes the edge off a film that had plenty to like. Others here have said plenty about that, so let me focus now on that flaw.Remember, Ruby works on her father's boat and her presence is potentially vital, since she is the only one aboard who can hear. One day, she unilaterally decides - without telling anybody - to take the whole day off to go to a lake with the boy she fancies.It's a lovely day out and advances their relationship. But in her absence, her father and brother are unable to communicate with the observer placed on board their boat, do not hear radio broadcasts or hailer calls and end up being boarded by the suspicious coastguard. This set of circumstances incurs large fines the family cannot afford and, worse still, could put them permanently out of business!And yet, when she finally turns up, Ruby gets upset that the family is "trying to pin this on me". In other words, even when confronted with the dire consequences, she refuses to assume any guilt for the damage her terrible lack of responsiblity has caused.That is not so surprising among teenagers, but the film copmpounds the problem by letting her get away with it and instead pins the blame squarely on the parents for expecting too much of their daughter. It was a burden to carry, but she was an apparently mature young lady who had been doing a reasonable job since she was very young and the family had organized itself around that. So they depended on her and she let them down, very badly!Yes, kids should be encouraged to pursue their (realistic) dreams, but the universe does not stop for that to happen and life in a society entails all kinds of basic responsibilities that have to be fulfilled in order for that society to function. That is a far more important lesson to teach the younger generations!Another is the importance of communication. Ruby not only comes close to ruining the family business, but also nearly destroys her budding singing future by letting down her tutor, giving him the impression she's undisciplined and wasting his time, because she does not explain (just offers vague excuses) the difficulties she is having in reconciling all the commitments she has assumed.
Outstanding and overwhelming touching, simply it's one of the best.

reviews.review_title: Along with Sound of Metal, one of the best films with characters from the deaf community

The movie is great from start to finish, but what really got me the most is when everything went silent to imitate what a deaf person hears on a regular basis.This made me think after finishing the movie about how people with disabilities struggle in our society. Why didn't we get at least one sign language class in elementary or middle school to at least have the basic knowledge to communicate? I'm aware that there's no one sign language around the world but at least each country should introduce their sign language to the curriculum.All in all, the movie was great and I highly recommend it.

reviews.review_title: A film that works despite its familiarity
reviews.content: The Sundance Film Festival has always been known for giving a great platform to unassuming films by little-known filmmakers. Many of the festival's winners have gone on to win prestigious awards. CODA could be the next candidate in which this scenario occurs. Not only is it one of the biggest crowd-pleasers of the year, but the coming-of-age story gives the sneezy cast of deaf-mute performers a chance to shine.It is important to mention that CODA is based on the French comedy Do You Understand the Béliers. Whereas in the original work, however, only hearing actors embody the almost exclusively deaf-mute family members, here it is people with the actual affliction. At the latest since Sound of Metal showed this fascinating group in such a grandiose way, deaf-muteness in films has been on everyone's lips. Director Sian Heder wraps this concept in a film reminiscent of coming-of-age stories like Lady Bird and Juno. The youngest member of the family, Ruby, is the only hearing one in her family and helps her loved ones make ends meet as a translator in a less tolerant society. The family owns a fishing business, into which several obstacles get in the way as the plot unfolds. But that is not the main story. Rather, the film is told through Ruby's eyes and accompanies her as she is torn between staying true to her family or pursuing her dream as a singer. 19-year-old Emilia Jones plays this character as authentically and adolescently as possible, and you buy into her almost impossible situation, but one that seems so remote from our point of view. The best moments in CODA occur when she shares emotional dialogue with her parents and brother. Although they only gesture with sign language, you follow the conversation as if it were the spoken word we are used to. This is thanks to the great performances of Oscar winner Marlee Matlin, Troy Kotsur and Laniel Durant. They seem very bizarre and different at first, but it becomes increasingly clear that they too have normal concerns and needs apart from their deafness. Eugenio Derbez, as Ruby's mentor and singing teacher, is also a constant in the protagonist's life that we wish we had.Out the back, CODA lives up to all the hype as a crowd pleaser. Some scenes press hard on the tear gland and are carried by great sung musical accompaniment. Before that, however, the film takes almost half the time to finally get going. This is detrimental to the film because the plot lost me a little after the long delay. One should not expect surprises anyway. The film follows a classic pattern, but the predictability does it little harm. Rather, the fact that the family conflict built up in the first half never fully unfolds. Only between brother and sister is there a reckoning, but this is not really pursued. In retrospect, however, this is forgotten, as Heder knows how to rely on elements towards the end that simply appeal to filmgoers. I fell for that too and that is the reason why I enjoyed CODA so much in the end. Viewed as a whole, however, the film has obvious weaknesses, which is why I cannot rank it among the top tier coming-of-age stories.

reviews.review_title: Much deeper and nuanced than it first appears
reviews.content: Where do I begin? Few movies have moved me that way this movie has. I see a number of reviews using terms like "formulaic" or "by the numbers", which may have some basis, however, do not for a moment believe that is a full assessment of this beautifully told story.(I'm not hating on Hollywood, they are, after all, in it for the money not the art, and to that end they do a fine job. However, CODA is yet another stunning example of how the film industry outside of Hollywood produces wonderfully wonderful work! This movie is a wee gem!)CODA explores how people's interpretations of situations can be vastly different, and often not recognised by those sharing those situations, even loved ones.It lets us know that sometimes we need to stop being selfless and to do things for ourselves, for the benefit of our sanity, desires, dreams, and dare I say it... our souls! Simultaneously, the story tells us why we must stop being selfish, dependent, negative, turning can't do / won't do attitudes, beliefs, and actions around, giving new strength to the characters. It is a coming of age story, but not simply a teen coming of age, not by a long way.There is one scene that I just know will last with me forever. These powerful scenes come along very rarely in cinema, Tom Hanks' interpretation of the opera in Philadelphia is one. Liam Neeson in Schindler's List when he is counting the number of Jewish lives his Nazi pin could have bought is also one. Likewise, Jean Valjean's death scene / the finale of Les Misérables, is another example of a truly rare and exceptionally crafted moment (IMHO). CODA too, has one of these moments, and while I'd wager most would say it's the scene where Ruby sings to her father on the back of their pickup truck. For me, it's the duet scene, the scene we know is going to be pivotal, but then... That moment! Right there! Where everything changes, everyone becomes aware of more than themselves for a mere moment, and it's transformative in the most beautiful way, without a word being uttered, nor a sound being made!I will happily re-watch this movie, and joyfully re-experience those emotions again and again, I'm certain of this.To me this felt authentic, the acting was very much on point, (everyone is on point). It's clear Emelia Jones worked very hard to prepare for this role, highlighted by the fact that, at no moment ever does she look uncomfortable working on a fishing trawler, nor does she look like anything less than someone who has signed to communicate her entire life! She does, for the most part, look uncomfortable singing, but she's supposed to, and yet, It's apparent she has the singing chops to pull of the big singing moments.Look, do yourself a favour, if you haven't seen CODA yet then watch this movie! If you have seen it, then watch it again!Thank you for making CODA.

The Rossi family runs a fishing boat off the coast of Massachusetts and Ruby (Emilia Jones) is the only member of the clan who is not deaf. She joins the high school choir during her senior year and finds herself caught between, on the one hand, the demands of her (very close-knit) family, and on the other hand her aspirations to pursue voice in college.While this is a remake of a 2014 French movie, this reboot carves out its own identity by placing the material in the working class, fishing sub-culture of Gloucester, Massachusetts. That atmosphere added grit to the film, and the audience never doubts the genuineness of the setting. The parents (Marlee Matlin, Troy Katsur) have a wonderful chemistry and Ruby's brother (Daniel Durant) is also fantastic; and Emilia Jones absolutely shines as Ruby. We quickly learn that, despite the challenges presented by being deaf and the chaos caused by that, their family life is animated by love. I was touched by the honesty of their interactions and the beauty of their shared lives in spite of their common disability. This made Ruby's dilemma all the more poignant; how can she leave them given their dependence on her, but how can she not follow her own dreams?In our cynical day, this movie was uplifting--not by foisting a pre-conceived message on the audience--but by simply allowing the beauty of the Rossi's family life to radiate. The writing is intelligent and witty, and the dialogue, both spoken and signed, is heartfelt and often hilarious. The movie doesn't glorify the characters merely because they have a disability, nor are they prevented from acting out their full humanity--the highs and the lows--with integrity.This is a beautiful movie and worthy of the Best Picture award at the Oscars. Frankly, it caught me off guard that such a positive film--one not inundated with politically correct virtue signaling, took the top prize. This was heartening.

It is exceedingly rare for a performance to master so many disparate nuances as that which Emilia Jones has accomplished. You will believe every fiber of her story...the signing, the singing - and likely not so silently cheer for her (and her family) to achieve a happily-ever-after outcome!

reviews.review_title: Not different from the average Disney Channel movie
reviews.content: Frankly, I'm disappointed that CODA won the Oscar for best movie, and I don't understand why the reviews and ratings are so high.Don't get me wrong, the goal of giving space to deaf people is noble, and it was about time that Hollywood started this process; nonetheless, this movie is nothing but sappy.The actors did a great job and their performances were by far the most enjoyable thing of the film, but the plot was really basic, and to me it wasn't different than the Disney Channel movies I used to watch when I was a kid. The obstacles that the protagonist has to face to achieve her dream are overcome very easily, and there is really no tension: from the very beginning, you just know there will be the happy ending with the girl going to music school, so the whole plot feels sort of fake.You can't even say that the concept is original, since it's basically a copy of a previous french movie.On a positive note, I think the dialogue between the protagonist and her dad is really moving, I admit I might have shed a tear in that moment.As an adult, I think I am too old for this kind of movie, but I would recommend showing it to kids or young adolescents.

reviews.review_title: Completely formulaic coming-of-age story that adds nothing to an already oversaturated library

However, the family does not support the protagonist because they need him/her to help their family business/does not believe the arts are a practical pursuit for financial independence/is anti-art. Ultimately the protagonist has to choose between his/her family or his/her passion, but whatever choice the protagonist makes, everything is reconciled at the end. Or not.Everyone and their mother has told this story. 90% of Japan's animated productions tell some variation of this story.Some try to add something new or subvert or satirize the genre in some way to stand out. Not CODA! CODA relies on its gimmick of using deaf actors to play deaf characters to emotionally manipulate the audience. Not dissimilar to how Boyhood was shot over decades.Don't get me wrong, it's great that deaf actors are getting representation, I just wish it wasn't just for a stupid gimmick.The film is passably made for what it is, but it does NOT deserve its accolades.TL;DR Skip this, and just rewatch Dead Poets Society instead.Or the Weird Al movie, which is a brilliant satire of the coming-of-age genre.

Siân Heder brings a powerful story to the screen with her Sundance breakout. Apple's history-making $25 million dollar purchase from the Sundance Film Festival brings together a sensational ensemble and a well-written screenplay. Showcasing stellar performance from its entire cast ‘CODA' is a touching film that shines a light on the deaf community. Adapted from the French film ‘The Bélier Family', Heder's film rectifies one of its predecessor's many faults by casting actual deaf actors in the roles of deaf characters. As well as its record-breaking price tag, ‘CODA' has gone on to win a plethora of awards such as, 3 Academy Awards at the 94th Oscars, including Best Picture, 2 SAG awards and 2 BAFTAs. The film is the first feature with a predominantly deaf cast to win Best Picture, and Troy Kotsur is the first deaf actor to win a BAFTA.

‘Locke & Key' star Emilia Jones stars in the film's lead role, bringing the character of Ruby Rossi to the screen, a Massachusetts teenager who happens to be the only hearing person in her deaf family (brought to life by brilliant performances from Marlee Matlin and Daniel Durant and a sensational performance from Troy Kotsur). Ruby must work to juggle high school, working on her family's fishing boat and her new commitment to the school choir. When singing becomes a passion for Ruby she's faced with the decision to apply for Berklee College of Music; Ruby finds herself at a crossroads – leave her family and follow her dreams or stay in Gloucester, Massachusetts, and continue to work in the family business.

The film features electric performances from its entire cast while giving audiences an insight into a community more-or-less forgotten about by society – showing viewers how, even in a crowded room, deaf people can feel isolated. Troy Kotsur's Oscar, BAFTA and SAG award-winning performance is arguably the standout part of ‘CODA', with his only spoken line being enough to draw audiences to tears. Emilia Jones' performance is equally marvellous, her performances brilliantly show audiences what it's like to be in her position as a CODA (child of deaf adults), acting a both interpreter and daughter at times. ‘CODA' is a film not entirely dissimilar to Darius Marder's 2019 drama ‘Sound of Metal' starring Riz Ahmed and real-life CODA Paul Raci. Both films heavily revolve around deafness and being deaf, and each happened to be nominated for Best Picture, with ‘CODA' going onto win the distinguished accolade.

Despite coming off as a child-friendly coming-of-age drama, ‘CODA' quickly grows on you as the film progresses, turning from a cliché film into an emotional, heart-warming tear-jerker. ‘Pam & Tommy's Paula Huidobro provides the film with pleasant visuals that make ‘CODA' all the more enjoyable to watch. Heder's eloquent screenplay skilfully walks the line between comedy and drama that is thoroughly entertaining and carefully pulls you into its powerful story. The film cleverly balances themes and ideas that some may not be all that familiar with ones that are more known to mainstream/hearing audiences, taking those things and transforming them into a dynamic and feel-good film that you can easily get behind. Emilia Jones also lends her voice to the film's soundtrack, providing vocals for six songs featured throughout the film, including a passionate cover of Joni Mitchell's 1969 song ‘Both Sides Now'.

Siân Heder's Oscar-winning adaptation tells a story that resonates with CODAs across the globe and builds a bridge between deaf and hearing audiences through uplifting storytelling and knockout performances. ‘CODA' tells the tale of a teen torn between two lives as she struggles to make her way in the world. Despite being a formulaic film in which you can easily predict what's going to happen next, Siân Heder manages to create something that greatly succeeds in being a stirring familial affair set to stand the test of time as feel-good crowd pleaser.

There's a lot to like in this movie.  Or there could have been a lot.
The top of that list is - what if they did not 'translated for the audience the signed language? You'd have to figure out what the deaf characters are 'saying.' And I tried it - without the subtitles - and it worked for me. It was like watching a silent movie. It added a lot to the movie - it made it special - a movie about a deaf family and, like them, you had to figure out what people were 'saying' throw their body language. The acting was good enough to do that- all top notch, even if a little over the top. 
But even that great idea would not have saved this movie from mediocrity. The problem is the story line - it's very trite. The problems raised by the plot are not real. There are so many simple solutions to these 'problems' that I couldn't understand why they didn't discover them - these people are deaf but they still are smart. Need a speaking member of the crew on the fishing boat? Hire one. It's not like that is a problem. Oh, but then how will the hearing person deal with the deaf father and son on board the boat? Well, the deaf son/brother meets a girl in a bar and they communicate very well by texting to each other. Sounds like a solution.  You can even turn on the vibrate function so you won't miss any messages. 
The subplot about how the government is ruining the livelihood of the fishermen is just plain ridiculous. And the idea that this family - so poor that Mom worries about a $2 purchase - could afford to start a co-op and rent a warehouse - it's just silly. OK, that's the story and I can accept it. But just don't make it so silly.
Of course, the real story is about how a family copes with a child who is about to leave the nest. Yes, it is hard. And while the family is poor the story throws in a 'rich boy' character to say that while the family in question is poor, they love each other and laugh, as opposed to his rich but sad family. Really? 
Yes, telling the story of a deaf family using deaf actors is a great idea, but please, do it honestly.

I avoided this for a while, worried that it may be a clichéd sort of heartwarming, formulaic comedic drama that we've seen many times in the past. It is many of those things; it is also often genuinely funny and insightful. A film that breaks this many barriers and thus holds the level of significance it does should probably be a bit more than that, however. That most of the narrative beats of the film are entirely predictable is a shame, but it's also true that several good performances do elevate it to a degree. A brilliant use of sound dropping away in a music performance scene gives to hearing audience members the most profound moment of empathy in the film; there are other moments, and sequences that hit home in their own way. Emilia Jones' singing voice is something special too, it's not hard to see her career taking a distinctly musical direction from here on out. Ultimately it has more to recommend it than other similar films, and its heart is undoubtedly in a good place. But it also could, and perhaps should, have been more too.

CODA is a heart-warming and feel-good movie that will leave audiences both crying and laughing. It follows the story of Ruby, a deaf teenager who is the only hearing member of her family. While she loves them dearly, she feels like an outsider in her own home and longs for a life outside of their small town. When she falls in love with a hearing boy and starts to pursue her dreams of becoming a singer, she must decide between the life she wants and the family that she loves.

CODA is an uplifting story about following your dreams and being true to yourself. It features amazing performances from its cast, particularly Emilia Jones as Ruby who spent nine months learning American Sign Language to play her role. The film is beautifully shot and captures the stunning landscapes of Cape Cod. It's an emotional and feel-good movie that will stay with you long after the credits have rolled.

This is the story of an attractive 17 year old girl with a beautiful singing voice who is held back by her selfish and cruel parents. The parents in this film are truly evil and sadistic. Both of them are deaf and yet they had two children, knowing that they could inherit their curse. The protagonist is the lucky one, meanwhile her poor brother must go through his entire life never hearing music or the sound of his sister's voice. The film makes it clear that deafness is a tragic handicap that makes it much harder for someone to earn a living, have a social life, and communicate with anyone who isn't deaf. The mother actually tells her child that she wished she had been born deaf so that she  would love her more. Seriously. The family earns their money in a barbaric fashion by casting wide nets into the ocean, dragging up all forms of sea life such as fish and crabs. They are then left to painfully die out of water and stabbed mercilessly by the father as he sorts them. He teaches his daughter to step on the fish as they lay dying to fit more into some buckets. Without their daughter the father and brother cannot run a fishing business. They won't hear coast guard alerts. They won't hear the cries of anyone in trouble. So they rely on their daughter, who can hear, to help them. That is the conflict of the story. The ending is predictable and yet fails to wrap up the conflict. There is additional conflict between the protagonist and her chorus teacher, her duet partner, and a school admissions board. It tries to be a heartwarming film, but the parents are so beyond belief in their cruelty to animals and to their daughter that I felt no sympathy for them at all.

CODA stars Emilia Jones, Troy Kostar, Marlee Martin, Eugenio Derbez and Daniel Durant in a coming of age film that follows a girl that is the only person in her family that isn't deaf, which causes some issues when she finds her passion for singing.

This film is something I had never seen before. I've seen plenty of films that have deaf characters but I've never seen something that dives into that life the way this film did. We get to see all of the complications that come with being deaf and it really opens your eyes and makes you think about what it would be like.

Emilia Jones plays the lead character Ruby Rossi and does an amazing job. You become extremely invested in this character fairly early on so throughout the entire film you are rooting for her and you feel the emotions she feels when dealing with her parents that can't really understand her passion for music.

On the other side of this film we see her family who are trying as hard as they can to live a comfortable life. Troy Kostar is phenomenal in his role. His ability to act and display emotion without speaking is something I've never seen before. Daniel Durant and Marlee Martin are both amazing butt Troy is the stand out for me.

This was also extremely funny in my opinion. There are moments that are fairly cheesy but overall they did a great job of making this film not only compelling and emotionally gripping but also entertaining.

Overall CODA is an amazing film. It gives us a coming of age story that we've seen before but adds to it with the deep dive into the life of being the only hearing person in her family.

Slice of life, fly on the wall, classic storytelling with excellent character development, fabulous casting, top knotch acting and spectacular cinematography. However, having spent a career as an ASL interpreter, then later a counselor I shared the stage with many CODAs and advocated for independence and equity for countless deaf families and individuals since 1983. This is where this movie falls flat, it appears to be contemporary setting, but there is no way in 2020s that there would be town meetings, school plays, Coast Guard hearings without a certified interpreter, especially in a coastal Massachusetts town!!! Deaf families are not that dependent or helpless these days. Place this movie pre-ADA 1990, in a rural town in Maine and it would be more believable. Because, yes deaf people experience the level of discrimination depicted in this poignant film, and children of deaf adults have lived through many embarrassing appointments or been bullied and torn between living their dreams or their family's. 
Final note: Emilia Jones has a fabulous voice and mastered ASL WHILE SINGING!!! You have to literally think in two different languages at the same time. Now, Eugenio Derbez was right out of the passionate-choral-director-living-his lost-dreams-through-students playbook. As an seasoned vocalist, I have worked with and been equally inspired by a Mr V and found his character a fantastic addition to this well developed cast. But let's not forget Daniel Durant who nailed the deaf sibling role amongst such strong, stylized actors as Matlin and Kotsur. And Ferdia as the guitar strumming,  innocent boyfriend…WOW!!!

Just because you can't hear doesn't mean you still can't dream 
Apple TV+ presents one of the rare stories for a big community of individuals that's largely ignored adapted from The Belier Family 
Ruby Rossi was born normal yet her entire family is deaf making her a CODA or Child of Deaf parents 
She works on a fishing boat in Gloucester, Massachusetts but dreams of singing her heart out on stage 
Joining choir club she's drawn to her duet partner and passion for singing 
Yet the rest of her family questions whether or not she should go through with it since Ruby has been taking care of them all her life 
Can they manage without her translating for everyone? Or is she going to be forced to stay to keep the fishing afloat?
Ruby also has to deal with the constant mocking from the student body given her relatives' home life 
There are plenty of voices with something to say, what do we all have to say?, nobody is truly helpless, be happy to know who you are

CODA [SPOILERS] starts with killing animals and a smelly fart. Just leave that out. Daughter sings on the boat so when she sings later on a cliff it's not a surprise she can sing. The money problems are phoned-in, contrived. Choir teacher is a tired trope. Marlee Matlin, the actress, talks. Why does she not talk in this movie? Why is there no lip reading? Deaf culture issues (oralism v manualism) go unexplored. Why was Ruby made fun of at school for talking like a deaf person when her parents don't talk? How did she learn to talk? Too much goes unexplored. Did Miles know about the bullying? Parents feel quirky for quirkiness sake - day sex? Silly. A lot of false conflicts. What's the point of the cliffs? Director Siân Heder's coming of age drama CODA (Child of Deaf Adults) (2021) is a truly moving picture with astoundingly creative filmmaking. Heder's direction feels completely in control and natural. Her ability to balance the coming of age comedy of high school friendship, relationships, choir practice, college applications with musical singing auditions and family drama centered around fishing work and deaf accessibility is incredible. CODA easily earned their nomination for a Best Picture Oscar at The Academy Awards. I hope CODA wins!

Siân Heder's direction is very poignant as she puts you into the shoes of a poor family, further struggling in this Massachusetts fishing community because three of the four of them are deaf. You listen to beautiful music for the singing passages, but it is the unheard pleas and troubles of people who cannot hear that reverberates loudest about CODA. She lets you feel like you're in this quaint and close-knit family dynamic with her intimate dramatic scenes with realistic and grounded conflicts. Heder's heartfelt depiction of how deaf people must live in America also inspires courage with Emilia Jones' fantastic singing abilities and musical journey. I'm so happy to see more lady directors like the bright shining star Siân Heder rise to the forefront of cinema.

Writer Siân Heder's sincere care for the deaf community is self-evident as she empathetically relates viewers to their daily struggles as real people with their own perspectives. Seeing the numerous ways that deaf humans have to communicate with other deaf people and hearing individuals is fascinating and touching. Heder's dialogue feels so interesting as CODA is hilarious with outrageous jokes and devastatingly real with her tumultuous family drama. This story is certainly similar to other coming of age comedies and dramas, but it is entirely unique in its execution. I loved how specific and playful her writing feels. Honestly, Heder should have been nominated for her fearsome direction and inventive script.

English actress, singer, songwriter Emilia Jones is a charming delight as Ruby Rossi in CODA! I found Emilia Jones absolutely gorgeous with a magnetic personality. Her effervescent natural beauty and captivating facial expressions make her dreamy. She has very expressive eyes to act out Ruby's shy natural and hurt feelings. Jones has a subtle grace to her delivery. I am totally blown away by Emilia Jones. Her impressively fast sign language skills are as mind boggling as her powerful singing prowess. I don't even understand how Emilia Jones could be so talented to act with a believable American accent instead of her natural, cute, posh English accent. She simultaneously was acting, signing, and singing in the finale audition! Her shy and dreamy lead actress performance in CODA will remain one of the coming of age genre's finest claims to fame. How Emilia Jones for CODA or Rachel Zegler for West Side Story were not nominated for Best Actress Oscars over Jessica Chastain or Nicole Kidman will forever be lost on me. I cannot wait to see Emilia Jones again.

Trailblazing, American, deaf actress Marlee Matlin is excellent as Ruby's tough and unsympathetic mother Jackie Rossi. She really plays it mean and selfish, before Jackie opens up to her daughter. Matlin is a class act and a brilliant actress and CODA proves her versatility. I do not understand how Marlee Matlin is getting passed up for Best Supporting Actress everywhere as she's as gripping as Troy Kotsur.

Everyone will love groundbreaking, American, deaf actor Troy Kotsur as Ruby's amiable and frustrated fisherman father Frank Rossi. His expressive sign language and hilarious delivery make him so charming and fun. The scene where he touches Ruby's throat to hear how wonderful her singing is really moved me. No wonder he is sweeping Best Supporting Actor all awards season!

Daniel Durant is incredibly nuanced as Ruby's deaf fisherman brother Leo Rossi. I completely understood how his character felt when the other fisherman mocked him for being deaf or when he perceptively understood how Ruby felt about singing. He's really quite remarkable in his own right. The only reason Daniel Durant is not getting more recognition is because he's surrounded by genius actors delivering equally impressive performances. Canadian actress Amy Forsyth has real chemistry with Durant. She is very pretty and funny as Ruby's outgoing friend Gertie.

Mexican actor Eugenio Derbez is a riot as Ruby's encouraging choir teacher Bernardo Villalobos. His energetic charisma, funny delivery, deft piano playing, and skillful singing are all mesmerizing. Ferdia Walsh-Peelo is quite nice and likable as Miles. His singing is pleasant as is his guitar playing, but it is his personable manner that really redeems Miles after his initial standoffish behavior and cruel mistake that hurts poor Ruby's feelings.

Geraud Brisson's swift editing makes CODA's 112 minutes swim by briskly for a pleasant 112 minutes. It feels fast paced with sweet montages of fishing, singing, or hanging out that are quite effective. I love the hard cuts between Ruby having to go from fishing all day to attending school and choir practice that really let you feel how busy and overworked she is constantly. Paula Huidobro's cinematography is gorgeous with all these stunning wide shots of the ocean or the Rossi's family fishing vessel. The medium shots during the conversations and the close-ups of faces are very tender. CODA has a very personal and intimate feel. I loved all the natural scenery from the sea to the quarry and trees.

Diane Lederman's production design is great as you see how poor the Rossi family is supposed to be with their messy house that is essentially a large wooden shack. Paul Richards' art direction focuses on light pouring in naturally through windows and across the boat. I love how bright and vibrant CODA looks. For all the mean viewers and critics bashing CODA, I was actually taken aback by how sleek and creative the craftsmanship is in all aspects of CODA. Set decorators Chris Conroy, Vanessa Knoll, Deborah Kehs, Thyra Heder, Joshua Manning, Mazie Biswell, Christina Bauer, Sara Itkis, Steven Coutts, Christopher Doig, James Giovannucci, Jamie Joseph, Chris Sawtelle, Layla Calo-Fee, Setha Phongsavan, Collin Williams, and Jonathan Langeveld provide quaint set dressing and furnishings for this fishing family. From the house with scattershot posters and plates to the realistic fishing equipment.

Composer Marius de Vries' lovely score for CODA is mesmerizing with uplifting melodies and powerful songwriting. The music chimes in with a pleasant warmth and softness I liked. Sound designers Martin Pinsonnault, Stéphane Bergeron, Paul Col, Alexandra Fehrman, and David Tremblay do more than just create all the ambient noises around CODA's town. Their cutting out sound or fading out noises to simulate what it is like to be deaf is creative genius. Meanwhile, they beautifully and clearly mix Emilia Jones' transcendent vocals. The singing passages sound pristine and Emilia's soft voice sounds all the more divine thanks to their authentic acoustic mixing. CODA has a crisp and up front vocal mix.

Costume designers Brenda Abbandandolo and Courtney Stephens create layered fisherman garments and gear alongside super cute sweaters and plaid shirts for Emilia Jones attending school. Everything she wears feels practical, modern, and something her small town girl Ruby would actually adorn. Juliet Loveland and Krystle Poulin's make-up lets Emilia glow with a natural radiance.

In conclusion, CODA remains one of 2021's finest crafted films and most earnestly entertaining movies.

Ruby Rossi is the hearing child of deaf parents who helps her folks (and her brother, also deaf) aboard the family fishing boat in their coastal New England town. Her problem: she sings like a nightingale--though she's rather shy about letting anyone know--and her high school choirmaster wants to take her under his wing and coach her. Will she allow him to? SHOULD she allow him to? "CODA"--or Children of Deaf Adults--is about how she learns to conquer her fears, wow audiences, let her pop flag fly--and even perform for her parents. There are lots of teenagers here, but not the brash, uber-confident ones that populate so many teen movies; these kids, led by Emilia Jones as Ruby and Ferdia Walsh-Peelo as her good-natured boyfriend Miles, are sweetly sincere and socially awkward and always a joy to watch. Ruby's scenes with Mr. Villalobos, played by Eugenio Derbez as the kind of dedicated teacher we all wish we'd had (at times the film resembles a seminar on how to properly deliver a tune), are never less than wonderful, and the subplot involving her parents' determined efforts to expand the family business (the ostracization of the Rossi clan offers a nice counterpoint to the main storyline) carries some emotional weight of its own. How will the Rossi family fare? Will Ruby realize her dream? With Marlee Matlin and Troy Kotsur as Mom and Dad, and Daniel Durant as brother Leo. It's already received a number of accolades, and deservedly so. Like a thirty-pound tuna wrestled out of the sea, this one's a keeper.  Buy a ticket, and bring the Kleenex.

CODA is about an 18-year-old named Ruby who is the only one in her family of four without a hearing impairment. Her father is a fisherman, and she needs to help her dad with fishing since he can't hear. For example, if he violates a fishing code, the Coast Guard calls him, but he cannot respond because he can't hear the call.  That's when Ruby comes in handy. Ruby's passion is singing. Her dream is to go to the Berklee College of Music. She finds out about a chorus group and joins it, which leads to some conflicts—primarily that her family relies on her, but she also wants to live her life and go to college.

CODA, which stands for "child of deaf adults", is an outstanding film (with many awards and nominations) that is a remake of the 2014 French film, La Famille Bélier. Sian Heder wrote and directed this beautiful adapted screenplay. Not only is this film heartwarming and comical at the same time, but it also lets the audience experience what it is to be deaf to the point of feeling vulnerable by not experiencing the joy of a live concert. My favorite part is when Ruby performs a song on stage with her family watching in the crowd. This is the most interesting and heartwarming scene because when they cut out the audio you get to see the dad's point of view. You really feel what he experiences as a deaf person.

There are many morals to this film, but the main one is that no matter what you suffer from or who you are—or even how you look—we are all humans. We should all be treated equally, and we are each unique in our own way. CODA does have some sexual scenes and foul language.

An incredibly sensitive and thoughtful look at the deaf community, the problems they face in their everyday lives and the person who ends up struck in the middle. The arguments in the film largely take place in near-silence, which is not only realistic, but demonstrates just how good the acting is, as the performers have to express themselves without so much as raising their voices. The story is fairly predictable, with the protagonist bouncing between what she wants to do and what is expected of her, but the writing, acting and direction is enough to make it feel fresh, and for the themes to feel resonant. It sheds light not just on the deaf community, but also the plight of hard-working fishermen and women who break their backs day in and out and yet still get dumped on from those ‘above them.' Their fighting back against their superiors is almost a metaphor for their fighting for societal acceptance, and the film is smart enough not only to show how people have varying reactions to deaf individuals, but that those same individuals are not, by any means, perfect. A lesser filmmaker would have portrayed the deaf family as being innocent angels fighting against an evil world, but we're shown their very humans flaws. Hypocrisy, dishonesty, selfishness etc. These are things that everybody can understand, and presenting the family in a more realistic light makes them more believable. It can be funny and emotional in the same scene, and it hopeful without having to resort to mawkishness. It's a great to see a film about a minority that doesn't condescend or patronise, and isn't afraid to highlight faults wherever they lie. CODA is, simply, a great movie, and I hope it that as many people see it as possible. It honestly, truly deserves it.

CODA (2021) is a wholesome story of a family who are all deaf, except for Emilia Jones' Ruby Rossi. The story is told in a way which feels natural and doesn't force any of its plot lines in as it deals with the struggles Ruby faces with wanting to help her family and pursue her own passion in music. The contrast of her love for music and her family who cannot hear is beautifully told as they don't understand why she has such a love for it. While it is heavily involved in her life, the music side of the story never takes the spotlight away from the sweet family dynamic, both storylines complimenting each other really well.

Not only is CODA (2021) a sweet story about music and this family dynamic, but also serves as a good coming of age story for Ruby Rossi as she grows throughout. The heavy involvement of ASL provides more coverage into the life of a deaf person.

It's impossible to hear the sentence "Funny how?" in any movie and not immediately get flashes of Joe Pesci. 

After being really wowed by the use of sound in relation to deaf characters in Sound of Metal, introducing and removing it during key moments to hammer home character development, CODA seems relatively safe by comparison. Plenty of traditional elements - the coming-of-age storyline, the liberation through expression, the testy but loving family dynamic - are each done well but aren't necessarily original by themselves, nor is the film's main differentiator (the deafness of several characters) particularly deeply integrated. That said, the film is perfectly serviceable, hitting many of the right narrative notes with characters that fill comfortable family roles without feeling boring, taking on a full range of expressiveness rather than overemphasizing the deafness or letting it define their characters (Troy Kotsur as Frank is a particularly entertaining and relatable dad). Nice, sweet, not a particular classic. (3/5)

Ruby Rossi (Emilia Jones) falls under the category of CODA, a Child Of a Deaf Adult. Her mother (Marlee Matlin) and father (Tony Kotsur) and her older brother (Daniel Durant) are all deaf, and she is the only member of her household with the ability to hear. She's balancing working for her family on their fishing trawler, maintaining good grades in school, and possibly pursuing scholarships to enroll at a music and fine arts college for singing. Ruby's music teacher agrees to train her because he believes in her potential, but Ruby has to worry that her dream is something that cannot be shared with the people she loves most, and how would they all get on without her?

The framework of CODA is familiar to anyone who has watched a coming-of-age story or family drama, but it's the conviction and strength of character and sheer force of empathy that makes this movie a standout film for 2021. It's based upon a 2014 French film, The Family Beller, and follows many of the same beats from other sentimental family dramas about sticking out in your family and society, chasing your dream, often in conflict with your family's expectations, gaining that sense of inner strength and resolve, and mending differences in perspective with hard-fought and well-earned wisdom. It's familiar, but that doesn't mean under the right set of hands that it cannot still be resonant and emotionally gratifying. I do not hold the familiar formula against CODA, even as the family's goal and her personal goal come into direct conflict in sometimes forced manners. That's because the movie does an excellent job of establishing these people as characters, establishing the family dynamic as fraught but loving, and establishing a conflict that is direct and clear as far a major point of separation.

Ruby isn't just the only member of her family who can hear, she's also their vital lifeline to the outside world. She's looked upon as the family interpreter, a position they cannot afford to pay for someone else's services so the duties and responsibilities fall upon her. That's so much pressure to bear for one teenage girl, knowing that she's the link between her family's poverty-treading existence and possibly breaking free into a larger hearing community. She feels ostracized and awkward within her own family and outside of her own family. To the rest of the school, she's that "deaf family girl," and it's remarked that when she began high school she had an accent reminiscent of what deaf people can sound like, a point that her peers cruelly imitate. She worries she will forever be defined by her family's disability even if she doesn't share it. However, within her family, she feels ostracized because she's different. She wonders if her mother wishes that she too were deaf, and during a heartfelt late-night talk, mom actually admits that upon her daughter's birth she did feel disappointment when Ruby had hearing. While she knows sign language and has grown up with these loving figures, she'll still always be the one who's different, the one who hears the insults her family cannot.

The film does a remarkable effort about contextualizing Ruby's fears and frustrations of being held captive in two different worlds, neither feeling fully accepted or whole, and that's why her embarking on a personal dream that her family can never fully appreciate feels so significant. Part of Ruby might feel that singing is selfish, especially if it means limiting her family's upward mobility by eliminating their unpaid interpreter, but it's the thing that makes her most happy, a special gift that her family will be excluded from. There's a wonderful moment toward the end of the movie where Ruby's father asks her to sing to him, and he puts his hands along her shoulders and neck to feel the vibrations, and his awed and tear-stricken face is so moving, as he so desperately wants to indulge too in the beauty of his daughter's voice. While occasionally the film goes overboard pounding these two conflicting paths into forced collision (family vs. self), the movie is personal with its big problems and personal with its big triumphs, making it transcend the trappings of formula.

Writer/director Sian Heder got her start on Orange is the New Black, and that TV series' hallmark has been its enormous sense of empathy for its diverse characters. This is evident in Heder's screenplay and her observational, detail-rich simple storytelling that immerses you in this world, so even while you recognize more familiar made-for-TV plot turns, the genuine authenticity makes the movie feel like its own unique story. Heder's direction is delicate and places the attention squarely on her performers. There is one stylistic move late in the film when Ruby's family comes to her choir recital in support. They look around for cues when to applaud, and their minds wander as they sign about other menial topics like grocery lists, and you understand why once Heder drops you into their perspective. For a minute, the sound disappears, and you're left studying facial expressions for cues like them. While we can imagine being deaf, it's another matter to experience it and try and understand.

The acting is another laudable merit for CODA. I personally want three Oscar nominations for this clan, Jones (Locke & Key) for Best Actress, Matlin (Children of a Lesser God) for Best Supporting Actress, and Kotsur (Wild Prairie Rose) for Best Supporting Actor. Over the course of nine months, Jones learned American Sign Language and how to sing, which is surprising because I would have said she has a natural talent with singing. Her performance, as well as Matlin and Kotsur, feel so real, so nuanced, and so natural, like we've plucked these people from real life and given them this platform. It's the best credit you can give an actor, when they seemingly disappear into the character, and the character feels like a fully breathing, flesh-and-blood person. Even the small supporting roles are well cast, well acted, and contribute to the overall authenticity of the movie. Unlike the 2014 French original movie, all of the deaf members of the family are portrayed by actual deaf actors as well.

CODA was a sensation at the 2021 Sundance Film Festival, with Apple Films buying the rights for $25 million dollars, and it's easy to see why because it's such a satisfying, enriching crowd-pleaser and legit tear-jerker. There were several points that had me tearing up, and then fully crying, because I was so emotionally engaged with the family, their struggles, and their triumphs and outpouring of love. You might be able to see where the movie is headed because its template is familiar and formulaic, but it's the execution, the attention to detail, and the level of observational attention that elevates CODA and makes it so winning and so heartwarming.

"CODA," an acronym for "Child Of Deaf Adults," is the kind of film that's designed to make viewers feel bad if they speak ill of it. However, after screening it, I can't help but say that this manipulative, cloying, cliché-ridden, saccharin-encrusted offering lives up to every one of those guilt-inducing traps. Writer-director Siân Heder's second feature outing tells the story of a Gloucester, Massachusetts high school senior who's the only hearing member of a family of deaf individuals. She's torn between pursuing her passion for singing and staying with her parents and brother to help them sort out the family's troubled fishing business. At its heart, it's narrative terrain that's been covered a number of times before, albeit with different particulars. That in itself would be fine if it weren't for the trite way in which the material is presented here, a production laden with the aforementioned calculated, derivative qualities that make it ordinary instead of outstanding. The picture also suffers from a screenplay and direction riddled inconsistent character development, left-field plot twists, underdeveloped story threads and over-the-top quirks, making this an often-frustrating watch. Admittedly, the film has some genuinely heartwarming moments, such as a number of heart-to-heart conversations between the protagonist and her family members, as well as fine performances by Emilia Jones and Marlee Matlin, but those attributes are hardly enough to give this one a ringing endorsement. This might not be an awful film, but its premise certainly lends itself to a more engaging treatment than is present here.

CODA is a splendid film with a concept that brightens up the entire duration. The film is very focused on crafting Ruby and her family. It works well some of the time. It was captivating to witness how Ruby had to endure helping her deaf family run their family fishing business and how her family would react to some of the things they said. I honestly felt terrible for Ruby as she was getting treated very poorly by her peers at school and even her own family. This plot element is where my biggest issue with the film comes in. It gives off a teen movie vibe. Yes, the film categorizes in the coming-of-age genre. However, the film loads itself with tropes that you can find in a Disney Channel flick. This issue makes CODA feel slightly predictable. The cast makes up for this slight letdown as each actor is so good. Emilia Jones does an extraordinary job as Ruby and packs an emotional performance that brings CODA to new heights. It is incredible to see her handle all these complex situations while using ASL. Troy Kotsur is phenomenal as the father to Ruby. Even though Kotsur has a slightly weak character, he pulls through with some of the best moments in the film. Daniel Durant is solid as Leo, Ruby's brother. While he did not have enough power to make his character's actions feel warranted, his emotion is strong enough for it not to fall through. Marlee Matlin is who I connected least to, but she had a firm performance overall. Lastly, Eugenio Derbez is hilarious but emotionally powerful as Mr. V, Ruby's choir teacher. The characters in CODA have some strong actors attached to them. Yet, the characteristics the screenplay gives them are slightly weak. It is hard to believe that this family would treat Ruby this way. When Ruby expresses a slight interest in singing, her mom grins and replies with "If I were blind, would you want to paint?" Come on. That is a little much. Plus, the way Mr. V treated Ruby was sort of out of line. These instances fall into the cliche coming-of-age trope, and I wish the script felt slightly more unique. Writer and director Sian Heder had a unique concept, and some minor tweaking would have set this film apart from other coming-of-age dramas. Even though CODA has its hiccups, the film is such an enjoyable watch. Yes, the platitude characters and plot points can be a tad distracting. However, Troy Kotsur and Emilia Jones make this film feel larger than life. CODA emphasizes the struggles of being deaf while still being potent and fun. The Sundance Film Festival has always been known for giving a great platform to unassuming films by little-known filmmakers. Many of the festival's winners have gone on to win prestigious awards. CODA could be the next candidate in which this scenario occurs. Not only is it one of the biggest crowd-pleasers of the year, but the coming-of-age story gives the sneezy cast of deaf-mute performers a chance to shine.

It is important to mention that CODA is based on the French comedy Do You Understand the Béliers. Whereas in the original work, however, only hearing actors embody the almost exclusively deaf-mute family members, here it is people with the actual affliction. At the latest since Sound of Metal showed this fascinating group in such a grandiose way, deaf-muteness in films has been on everyone's lips. Director Sian Heder wraps this concept in a film reminiscent of coming-of-age stories like Lady Bird and Juno. The youngest member of the family, Ruby, is the only hearing one in her family and helps her loved ones make ends meet as a translator in a less tolerant society. The family owns a fishing business, into which several obstacles get in the way as the plot unfolds. But that is not the main story. Rather, the film is told through Ruby's eyes and accompanies her as she is torn between staying true to her family or pursuing her dream as a singer. 19-year-old Emilia Jones plays this character as authentically and adolescently as possible, and you buy into her almost impossible situation, but one that seems so remote from our point of view. The best moments in CODA occur when she shares emotional dialogue with her parents and brother. Although they only gesture with sign language, you follow the conversation as if it were the spoken word we are used to. This is thanks to the great performances of Oscar winner Marlee Matlin, Troy Kotsur and Laniel Durant. They seem very bizarre and different at first, but it becomes increasingly clear that they too have normal concerns and needs apart from their deafness. Eugenio Derbez, as Ruby's mentor and singing teacher, is also a constant in the protagonist's life that we wish we had.

Out the back, CODA lives up to all the hype as a crowd pleaser. Some scenes press hard on the tear gland and are carried by great sung musical accompaniment. Before that, however, the film takes almost half the time to finally get going. This is detrimental to the film because the plot lost me a little after the long delay. One should not expect surprises anyway. The film follows a classic pattern, but the predictability does it little harm. Rather, the fact that the family conflict built up in the first half never fully unfolds. Only between brother and sister is there a reckoning, but this is not really pursued. In retrospect, however, this is forgotten, as Heder knows how to rely on elements towards the end that simply appeal to filmgoers. I fell for that too and that is the reason why I enjoyed CODA so much in the end. Viewed as a whole, however, the film has obvious weaknesses, which is why I cannot rank it among the top tier coming-of-age stories.

High school crossroads.  So this is about a teenage girl (Emilia Jones).  Her entire family is deaf, and she is the only one who can hear.  She has a decision looming in her near future: does she pursue her musical abilities in post-secondary education, or does she abandon that by the wayside to help support the family fishing business?  Now this one caught my eye on Apple TV+ because the trailers looked intriguing.  Deaf people get so little representation in television and film, so I added this to my watchlist to check out at my earliest opportunity.  I'm glad that I did because this is one of the stronger films of the year.  The only thing I had heard about this beforehand was how it has scenes that will rip your heart out.  While that is mostly what the third act consists of, all of that would have been for naught if they didn't lay the groundwork in advance.  They take the time to make you like and connect with this family, and you can relate because this girl has normal teenage problems on top of her family's condition.  She's got a bit of stage freight, she gets lightly bullied, she has trouble talking to the boy she's crushing on, and she gets embarrassed by her parents.  All members of this family turn in impressive performances through ASL, but I think that Emilia Jones shines brightest.  She's a talented little actress who is cast age-appropriately as a high schooler and not only that, she has some pipes on her as well.  It reminded me in a way of Florence Foster Jenkins.  Not that she sings poorly, mind you, but she has to vary her talent as she learns the craft.  That is a difficult feat to pull off when you clearly already know your vocal range and abilities.  The story to this isn't anything new.  This is a coming-of-age tale at its core, and it has all of the moments that you would expect to see in that kind of story.  CODA gets by on the strengths of its performances, and I would be surprised to see a dry eye in the room if I watched this in a group setting.  My only real complaint is that the choir teacher played by Eugenio Derbez.  He felt a bit cartoony at times, and he went over the top in the same way that Taika Waititi has in the past to varying degrees of success.  I don't think it quite fit the tone at times, but it wasn't enough to spoil it for me.  This is a tear-jerker, and I feel that it successfully earned all of the waterworks that it got out of me.

CODA is a big hearted film of exuberant joy and real emotion. It wears its heart on its sleeve with wisdom and moments of triumph. CODA stands for Child of Deaf Adults and is the story of a small family in a fishing village in Gloucester, Massachusetts. Mother and father and son are deaf whilst Ruby, the daughter, is able to hear. They run a fishing business and Ruby helps them in that and also communicating with the outside world. She is also a very talented singer and when pushed by her high school music teacher she realises her gifts are great and perhaps another life lies beyond the small village she lives in. It comes to a head when she has the chance to audition at the Berklee School of Music in Boston. She is torn between staying to help her family and following her dreams. In of itself it's not a fresh story, but it is made fresh here by centering deaf people at the heart of the story. The film adeptly shows the family has the same hopes and dreams of any family. They are a close knit family and just wish the world would not treat them specially but just afford them the same opportunities as any other family. Young English actress Emilia Jones is wonderful as Ruby, showing not just a great voice but bringing a great deal of winning charm to the role. And once again its great to see Marlee Matlin shine again in such a prominent role as her mother. This film was a huge hit at Sundance this year and Apple paid a record $25m to secure the rights. You can see why as the film reeks of authenticity and emotional scope. It does well to be sentimental but not tip into cliche, a film that will actually make you laugh and cry. And that's not a bad thing actually.

Sian Heder's "CODA" is an empowering, heartbreaking and inspirational family drama that suggests disabled casting marks positive steps in the right direction for onscreen deaf representation. With her second feature, writer/director Sian Heder gives a voice to voiceless communities by creating compassionate portrait of a tighknit deaf family through disabled casting. It's the filmmaker's first attempt to humanize the hardships experienced by hearing children of deaf families, but she pulls it off effectively. Using spellbinding cinematography, Heder draws viewers into struggles faced by a hearing teen obligated to provide for her deaf family. Heder's decision to shoot the movie in a smalltown setting is risky, but it works immensely. It lends a sense of realism and authenticity to the movie missing from the original French film, making it feel like a lived-in place. Heder showcases immense control over sound design, editing techniques and music, using these elements to create an unforgettable cinematic experience. Heder's screenplay is also sensational, and expertly uses subtle sign-language to establish the compassionate bond between a close-knit deaf family. It's hard to not praise phenomenal performances from cast. Emilia Jones delivers a star-making performance as Ruby Rossi. With mesmerizing expressions, she conveys angst, compassion and lifelong resentments of a hearing  teenager that strives to make ends meet for her financially needy deaf family. The supporting cast is sensational and also worthy of recognition. Heder's decision to cast hard-of-hearing actors pays off tremendously. Troy Kotsur, in particular, leaves a lasting impression as Ruby's affectionate patriarch through meaningful gestures.   Although "CODA"  is undeniably an unforgettable family drama, ultimately it isn't a flawless film. If there's a minor drawback to the movie, it's slightly undermined by an unnecessary teen romance subplot that distracts from the deaf family's conflict. Nevertheless, fans of coming-of-age dramas will definitely enjoy "CODA" and so will movie-goers seeking meaningful entertainment. If Cinema has power to give voice to voiceless communities, it's time Hollywood honored deaf communities by giving them a loud rather than quiet place in an industry where they can peacefully chase dreams even when luck may not always be in their destinies.

Coda is both a more accurate and explicit depiction of the deaf community. It doesn't shy away away from presenting us the community in its entirety while also capturing our sympathy and empathy. It touches on family, love, and how we are as humans and how our experiences influence our decisions, whether right to wrong. But from our experiences and mistakes, we grow and learn and therefore, strengthen the love for the people we care about the most. Also, grab some tissues because you will shed a tear or a thousand tears. May this film not be forgotten in award season but regardless, it is timeless, therefore, it lives in our memories and in the cinema world forever.

CODA stands for Child Of Deaf Adults.  The movie debuted in Park City at the Sundance Festival back in January.  It won numerous awards and Apple purchased the distribution rights for 25 million dollars.  It was released a few weeks ago on Apple TV+ and disturbed to a limited number of theaters.  It is interesting that given the fact that Apple paid so much for the distribution that they are not actively promoting the film.  I've never seen any commercials for it and they are not really pushing it on Apple TV+.  The only reason I watched it was because I noticed it got a 96 rating on Rotten Tomatoes.

Let's go through some of the bad and then get to the good.  CODA is, for all intent purposes, a standard formulized "Feel Good" movie.  There are very few surprises here.  The main character is Ruby in a standard "Kid with talent but lives a hard life" role.  Enough to make you groan.  Also it has received a few mixed reviews from the deaf community for its portrayal of the family.  I can certainly understand that even though I won't even begin to say I can relate.

None the less…..The movie is not perfect however it gets very close.  Ruby is played by Amelia Jones, who gives the performance of a lifetime.  Her family is played by all deaf actors and, as an ensemble, their work is flawless.  I see so many movies where, in the end, I did not give a shit about any of the characters.  This movie lures you in and you find yourself caring for, rooting for the family.  And yes it is a tear-jerker.  I want to see this in a packed theater just to watch the crowd.  This is one of those rare movies that appeals to all.  It's love and magic.  

CODA is the best I have seen this year.  My belief is that it's a lock for a Best Picture nomination, Amelia Jones is in for Best Actress.  I could also see Eugenio Derbez getting a Best Supporting Actor nod as the music teacher. It's early still but "Classic" may be how this movie is described in years to come.

Sian Heder's English remake of the French film 'La Famille Belier' will feel very familiar to anyone who has seen Glee or any coming-of-age movie where the central character is torn between family and pursuing his/her personal dream. Solidly and beautifully directed, with a tastefully appropriate, though a little on-the-nose, soundtrack; the stand out here is the winsome performance by British newcomer Emilia Jones who, as Ruby, the only hearing member in a deaf family whose ironically constructed passion is singing, convincingly plays American and proves a deft hand in ASL. Learning from the mistake made by the French original, the deaf family members here are played by deaf actors and Troy Kotsur, Daniel Durant and Oscar winner Marlee Matlin's likeable portrayal of the close-knit and often excessively honest (and horny) Rossi family is the only unconventional element in a fairly conventional film. Essentially, there are three intertwined stories that will be neatly and predictably resolved by the end of the film, involving Ruby's crush on Miles (an unrecognisable Ferdia Walsh-Peelo from Sing Street); the family's struggling fishing business that sees the previously reclusive family opening up to others; and that difficult choice between family obligations and going to music college, under the tutelage of her Mexican music teacher, a funny and slightly flamboyant turn from Eugenio Derbez. Normally, the deaf element would constitute a fresh distinctive angle but coming so soon after the amazing Sound of Metal, even that's now been done and done better, though comparisons between the two may not be entirely fair. However, judged as the crowd-pleaser that it clearly aims to be, its wholesomeness and positivity is infectious and undeniable, even if the rom-com tropes and contrived conflicts that get resolved far too easily make this film feel too safe and sometimes, corny even.

"CODA" is the kind of feel-good story that Hollywood used to make. The big studios, of course, can't be bothered these days with much of anything that isn't a sequel, a reboot, and/or based on a comic book. So "CODA" is a modest-budget independent film, though one lucky enough to attract the attention of Apple TV+ at the Sundance Film Festival. This remake of a 2014 French film is set in Gloucester, Massachusetts, a fishing town north of Boston. It stars Emilia Jones, a wonderful actress I had never seen before, as Ruby, a teenager who dreams of singing but is held back by the fact that her mother, father, and brother, who are all deaf, are dependent upon her to keep the family fishing business afloat. Marlee Matlin, 35 years past her Oscar-winning performance in "Children of a Lesser God," plays Ruby's mother with warmth and humor and may find herself back in the gold derby again in the supporting contest. And she might be joined at the Oscar party by the well known (at least in Mexico and among Spanish-speaking audiences in the U.S.) Eugenio Derbez, who brings some nice layers to his role as the tough but inspirational music teacher who encourages Ruby to pursue her dreams. The entire film gives off a lovely glow that only the most churlish out there will resist. No grandstanding political statements being crammed down the audience's collective throats,; just good storytelling. Bravo!

What a refreshing film. Not a single cliche to be had. Ruby is torn between two loves, her family and music. She makes hard decisions with confidence and sacrifice. Emilia Jones fully captures every emotion of Ruby and steals your heart. She shows us what it is like to be a strong young woman in an, often times, cruel and unfair world. I found myself rooting for her whole family in different ways. The most refreshing part of this film was that, although they are surrounded by a hearing world, the Rossi family deals with the the normal struggles of any family, and as Miles describes to Ruby, have a perfect home. Absolutely charming story that will make you feel all the emotions. A+
Wonderful movie! Unique, funny and moving.

This film has it all. It is hilariously funny. I hadn't laugh this much all summer long and this film really help my brain release the endorphins. My ribs hurt from laughing. The film has a tremendous amount of heart. This was a tear jerker by the end. All of the characters are so lovable and reliable. Watching Frank Rossi describe how to put a condom on in sign language to Miles was just ...agghhh amazing.

Director Sian Heder knocked it out of the park with extremely laser precision on-point direction. Specially how he had the actors who played Ruby's parents react to the singing at the high school. Everything was so on point and believable. Emilia Jones was outstanding. Such a beautiful and talented redhead. Can you imagine how hard is to find an excellent actress that is also an amazing singer? Seriously, I am super impressed with the whole cast. If this is television, then Heder raised the bar very high. Not only was the direction fantastic, but so was the screenplay. It was witty, funny and intelligent. This should have been a theatrical film. Honestly, I'll keep it short because if I could, I could name about a dozen scenes in this film that I loved. It was one after another, freaking fantastic scenes.

The only con I can think of was the title. Why an acronym for such a beautiful film?

SOLID 10/10 and screw the haters. This film really deserved the 10.

An Apple+ Original about a high school student who was the only hearing person in her family. 

I already love the movie when it started out. There were many funny and clever jokes mostly from the main character's deaf parents that showed the tight relationship in the family. I was consistently entertained with what our main character had to go through because she was the only hearing person in her family.

This led to the main conflict for our main character. The struggle between family responsibilities and one's hope and dream was a familiar theme that is explored many times before. However, the story created a new and unique situation that had me sympathized with not our main character, but also her family members. The family dynamics worked so well that the situation even more conflicting.

Still, the movie had many sweet moments. The audition scene near the end was beautiful and got me emotional there. Also, Emilia Jones, who played the main girl Ruby, had a beautiful voice, and I loved every scene where she sang. 

As for problems, the progression was definitely a bit formulaic, but it didn't bother me much at all.

Overall, a sweet, beautiful, and unique slice of life/coming of age story. 9/10

rt_summary: Seventeen-year-old Ruby (Emilia Jones) is the sole hearing member of a deaf family -- a CODA, child of deaf adults. Her life revolves around acting as interpreter for her parents (Marlee Matlin, Troy Kotsur) and working on the family's struggling fishing boat every day before school with her father and older brother (Daniel Durant). But when Ruby joins her high school's choir club, she discovers a gift for singing and soon finds herself drawn to her duet partner Miles (Ferdia Walsh-Peelo). Encouraged by her enthusiastic, tough-love choirmaster (Eugenio Derbez) to apply to a prestigious music school, Ruby finds herself torn between the obligations she feels to her family and the pursuit of her own dreams.
